articleBody.value: In the darkest days of December this year, residents living in the Bel-Air neighborhood near Brighton's 12 Corners had no lights to guide their way.
In what's become a recurring issue for some of that community's oldest residential neighborhoods, wide swaths of the historic harp-shaped high-pressure sodium streetlights failed to light.

Brighton, like most municipalities in Monroe County, pays leasing fees to RG&E for its neighborhood streetlights, charging back the cost for those lights directly to the property owners. For example, live on Edgemoor Road in the Struckmar neighborhood and you pay $.37 per $1,000 of assessed value on top of your town taxes just to keep those outdoor lights on. For a homeowner with a $200,000 home, that's about $74 per year.
► MORE: 5 things to know about street lights

Deborah Hall is the coordinator of the Bel-Air neighborhood association, where the lighting district tax is $.51 per $1,000 of assessed value. She and other residents there are fed up with paying their lighting fees while getting what they believe is sub-par service from RG&E. Weeks can go by before street light outages are addressed and residents feel like RG&E is not responsive to resident complaints, she said.

"All that money we pay goes to RG&E and some of it is supposed to go for repairing and upgrading the system" said Hall, who has lived in Bel-Air for nearly three decades. "I know these old lights are trickier to repair, but RG&E has had lots of notice they'd have to do something and the residents here have been paying in since the 1920s."
All told, taxpayers across Monroe County fork over more than $5 million every year just to keep the lights on.

They're paying for lights on the expressways, on state roads, on county roads and within close-knit neighborhoods where children and families would otherwise walk to and from their destinations in the dark of pre-dawn and the murky haze of twilight.

The bill for those lights includes not only the electric power that keeps them lit, but also rental/maintenance fees in communities where the lights are leased from RG&E and National Grid, plus capital improvement costs for upgrading the often decades-old wiring that string the lights together, the poles and the bulbs inside.

And while the total cost is a tiny sliver of the more than $1.7 billion annually collected here via property taxes; every dollar counts as towns and villages butt up against the constraints of the state's property tax cap. Municipal officials are casting their sights on street lights as a way to shave costs, pare down the tax bills and make sure broken lights get fixed more quickly. Those savings come not only from no longer paying rental fees for the poles and light fixtures, but also in giving municipalities the power to convert their street lighting inventory over to longer lasting, high-efficiency light-emitting diode lights, commonly known as LEDs.
High efficiency

New York State is urging communities to buy their lights outright in order to save taxpayer money and make it easier to convert to LED lighting. Legislation passed last year helps clear the way, requiring utilities to make streetlights available to municipalities and have procedures in place to facilitate transfers.

According to a report prepared in 2014 for the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority, nearly three-quarters of all street lights outside of New York City are still utility-owned, with only about one in every four municipalities having stepped up to buy their lights. The report says if local governments owned and upgraded municipal streetlights they'd realize savings of more than $100 million on annual street lighting costs.

LED lighting can be as much as 65 percent cheaper to run than traditional lights and significantly decrease carbon emissions. In a report urging cities world-wide to switch to LED by 2025, The Climate Group says swapping for LEDs in the United States would be equivalent to taking 8.5 million cars off the roads.

"As municipalities struggle to find ways to save money while retaining adequate services for taxpayers, this legislation will make a significant difference in reducing the utility bill of localities, in which the cost savings can be truly substantial," said legislation sponsor Assemblywoman Patricia Fahy, D-Albany in a written statement. "Through owning their own streetlights, villages, towns, and cities can pave their way to an energy-efficient and environmentally-friendly future."

In a community-wide energy plan released in 2015, Rochester announced its plan to replace all 28,000 of its streetlights — which account for 25 percent of the city's annual energy costs — with high-efficiency LED fixtures. The plan estimates the city could save as much as $485,000 annually after swapping to LED bulbs, which can also last as long as 25 years. Advanced metering and dimming controls on the lights that would vary the intensity of the lighting depending on time of day, could potentially increase those savings.

In 2013, Los Angeles completed what was then the world's largest LED streetlight conversion program, changing over more than 140,000 street lights. That city is estimating more than $7 million in annual electricity savings as well as $2.5 million in avoided annual maintenance costs. That's emblematic of what's rapidly becoming a nation-wide initiative to swap over to LEDs. It's happening in cities from Boston to Seattle, and using LEDs from the start has become a common feature of state Department of Transportation projects requiring new street lighting.

Monroe County caretakes more than 4,600 street light fixtures on the expressways and about 1,000 more on state arterials and county highways. Terrence Rice, the county's director of transportation, said early planning is going on to make repairs to the system and do a full conversion to LED fixtures. The Department of Transportation spends about $1.2 million annually on operation and maintenance of the street light system, plus there's an additional $250,000 in this year's capital budget for fixes and for mapping out that conversion plan.

Rice said there will be eight projects spread over seven years to upgrade all lighting where it hasn't already been converted. Also included in the plans are fixes to deteriorating conduit, which has been problematic for keeping the bulbs lit during inclement weather.

He said about a quarter of the system has already been converted during state expressway and road projects on areas including Interstate 390 at the Kendrick Road interchange and around the Winton Road interchanges. As part of the upcoming 390/490/Lyell project, the state Department of Transportation will also be converting lights in that area to new high-efficiency bulbs.
Lori Maher, DOT spokeswoman, said using the newer technology is a part of most DOT road projects.
A pig in a poke

Bill Moehle, Brighton town supervisor, said this town is dissatisfied with RG&E's service and would like to purchase all of its streetlights, but the age and condition of the system, as well as the utility's suggested purchase price are significant hurdles. Back in 2008, he said, RG&E wanted just $250,000 for the street lighting system, but during talks in 2014 the new pricetag was upwards of $1 million.

The system there is antiquated, he said, and needs significant upgrades not only in the fixtures themselves — historic and oddly-shaped, making conversion kits less readily available — but also in the old conduits underground that run power to the light poles. Making all those fixes on its own could mean substantial town debt, said Moehle.
RG&E spokeswoman Juanita Washington said the age of the lights has been a challenge for the utility company.

"Brighton's decorative lights and facilities were installed nearly 100 years ago," she said. "Unfortunately, the parts and fixtures to maintain these lights are no longer manufactured and are not generally available elsewhere."

She said a portion of the circuits on Claybourne and Edgemoor roads will be upgraded with new circuitry and up-to-date fixtures starting in April, and crews will salvage usable lamp parts to help maintain the remaining historic fixtures.

"We're not in a position to buy a pig in a poke," Moehle said, adding that he will maintain pressure on RG&E to make fixes he and residents believe they've already paid for in the other neighborhoods as well.
In contrast, Greece was able to secure its street lights for $4.9 million from RG&E in 2016 and is already seeing rewards.

"We're already saving over $1 million a year," by not paying the leasing fees, said Bill Reilich, supervisor of the Town of Greece. His town is in the midst of planning for LED conversions. "In four years here, we'll be ahead of the game."

Penfield has owned its street lights since the mid-1990s. Currently, it owns and operates about 700 streetlights, with most located at main intersections of town, county and state roads and along other major transportation corridors.

Supervisor Tony LaFountain said the town spends about $187,000 annually to run those lights, and pays for them via a town-wide lighting district tax of roughly six cents per $1,000, as everyone generally benefits from well-lit intersections and main roads. There are also two neighborhood-specific lighting districts in the town, where residents living in particular areas pay an additional yearly fee for the lights on their residential streets.
LaFountain said savings have been substantial without leasing fees and the town is now looking toward a gradual LED replacement as a way to eke out greater cost efficiencies.

"It's about $600 per fixture to change out the old units to the new units, and that's one of the things our board has been taking a look at," he said. "If we just made the decision to go ahead and do it, it would cost about $450,000, so we're thinking 'why not eat the elephant one bite at a time here?' Going out to the taxpayers and saying we need $450,000 for streetlights all at once would be a tough pill to swallow."
MCDERMOT@Gannett.com
LED street light issues

Back in June, the American Medical Association sent out a warning that some high-intensity light-emitting diode, or LED, street lighting may come with unintended health effects. At issue is the amount of blue light the bulbs produce.

The lights can appear stark white, in contrast to the more familiar yellowish hues of common high-pressure sodium bulbs. That blue light, according to the AMA, can cause more glare and eye discomfort than traditional, less-efficient lighting. Also, the blue-rich lights can cause problems with sleep rhythms, causing people disrupted sleep among some people exposed to brighter residential nighttime lighting.

The term "color temperature' is used to describe the appearance of light emitted by bulbs. Color temperature is measured in degrees of Kelvin. Most commercial and residential lighting falls somewhere between the scale of 2000K and 6500K. The higher the Kelvin rating, the closer the light's color is to real sunlight. Many older-generation LED streetlights have a color temperature of 5000K to 6000K, The AMA recommends that communities look to lights with lower Kelvin ratings, closer to 3000K, which give off a more amber glow.

Terrence Rice, Monroe County's director of transportation, said the county will take the AMA recommendations into consideration while planning its upgrade along area expressways, and Lori Maher with the state Department of Transportation said the agency is also opting for lower-rated LED lighting where appropriate. In the upcoming 390/490/Lyell interchange project, the color temperature selected is 4000K.

articleBody.value: Perhaps I’m wrong about this, but I’m fairly certain the only NFL fan base that believes Chad Kelly could be the long-term answer at quarterback for their team is the tortured-for-too-long group that roots for the Buffalo Bills.

It’s the sound of sheer desperation from fed up fans hoping and praying that Jim Kelly’s nephew can do for the Bills what Jimbo did for the franchise 30 years ago, in essence a bolt of lightning striking in the same place.

Back then, No. 12 rescued Ralph Wilson’s team from extinction and ultimately led it to four consecutive Super Bowl appearances. Now, for whoever the Bills’ quarterback is, the task would be ending a playoff drought that stands at 17 unfathomable years.

Certainly it would make for a delicious provincial storyline - Chad Kelly, graduate of St. Joseph’s Collegiate Institute in Buffalo, coming home and reprising the role of savior that his uncle performed so remarkably during his Pro Football Hall of Fame career. However, just because his name is Kelly does not mean that young, oft-troubled Chad is the answer to the Bills’ never-ending quest for a franchise quarterback.

I checked several of the 2017 NFL draft prospect rankings lists, and Chad is projected as no better than a third-day pick, meaning somewhere in rounds 4-7. CBS Sports’ highly-respected evaluators peg him as a sixth-rounder for several reasons, not the least of which he’s damaged goods coming off a second torn ACL surgery on his right knee which will prevent him from playing in all-star games, working out at the scouting combine, and working out for individual teams this spring.

Kelly has a strong arm, arguably one of the best in this draft class; he has some of his uncle’s toughness and competitiveness; he has some mobility (though post-surgery, that might now be lessened); and he plays with a gunslinger mentality and a huge amount of bravado (just like Jim). Beyond that, he is a player with way too many negative boxes checked to be considered a potential difference-maker at the game’s most important position.

Kelly played in a spread offense at Ole Miss and his inability to read defenses is a red flag; he has been diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder which reportedly has made it difficult for him to learn and retain playbook verbiage, a real concern at the NFL level; his decision-making during games was often questionable, especially against the better opponents; and his mechanics are said to be flawed as he too often relies solely on arm strength to make a play which won’t work in the NFL.
► Ex-Bills on their way to the Super Bowl
► What should the Bills do with Tyrod Taylor?
► Listen to the latest SalSpeak podcast with Sal and Leo Roth

Then there’s the matter of his alarming lack of maturity and history of off-field problems. Clemson coach Dabo Swinney kicked Kelly off the team a few years ago, and Kelly had to resurrect himself at junior college before Ole Miss offered him a life-line prior to the 2015 season.

Kelly pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct after he was kicked out of a Buffalo nightclub shortly after accepting Ole Miss’s offer. At the scene that night, Kelly resisted arrest and said, “I’m going to go to my car and get my AK-47 and spray this place.”

In October, he attended a high school game in Buffalo between his alma mater, St. Joe’s, and rival Bishop Timon. When a skirmish on the field broke out involving his younger brother, Casey, Chad had to be restrained from getting involved. In November, a Snapchat photo popped up on social media of Kelly allegedly rolling a joint. There is some question about how old the picture is, but no matter how old it is, if it was Kelly, that’s a potential problem down the road in a league that frowns quite heavily on the use of marijuana.
At the Senior Bowl this week, Bills general manager Doug Whaley was asked several questions about his possible interest in Kelly, and Whaley offered up politically correct answers.

“With him, obviously the arm, it's undeniable,” said Whaley. “The arm is there and this is why we want to get in with him, get our hands on him, have our quarterback coach say, ‘Alright, we see you have the arm, tell me about your mind? How did you make these decisions? What are you supposed to be looking for? What types of defenses are you calling as in secondary play? Are you identifying the Mike (middle linebacker)?’”
What about the character issues? Isn’t that something to be concerned about?

“You have to, especially the way the NFL is with the personal conduct policy,” said Whaley. “You have to do as much research with the off the field stuff as the on the field. With him having Jim in his corner and probably a lot of people in his camp that have gone through this before, they're going to give him the right advice. It’s just, tell the truth.”

There’s no harm in the Bills doing Kelly the courtesy of bringing him in for an interview, if for no other reason because he’s a Kelly. But spending a draft choice on him, even in the later rounds, would be ill-advised, especially for a team that has to hit on all of its picks and doesn’t have the luxury of taking a flier on the relative of a local hero.
Taking my shots

► As an avowed hater of the Boston Red Sox, I’m thrilled that David Ortiz has retired from baseball. Now I just hope he stays retired. There has been some speculation that perhaps Ortiz will come back to play in 2017, if not all year, but maybe later in the season to help the Red Sox – a legitimate World Series contender – down the stretch. I really hope that doesn’t happen, especially after he was given the grand farewell tour last season. The Red Sox announced Thursday that they will retire his No. 34 in June, a well-deserved honor. If he’s actually wearing that uniform, it would be just a bit ridiculous, wouldn’t it?

► There are two players Yankees fans should be watching very closely this spring, because they need to come through if New York hopes to contend in the AL East, or in the wild-card hunt: Outfielder Aaron Judge and first baseman Greg Bird.

Bird showed promise in two months of action in 2015, but he missed all of last year with a shoulder injury. Mark Teixiera is gone, and the Yankees need Bird to step in and be the full-time first baseman. Judge has been a tease ever since he entered the organization, but when the big guy got called up in August, he was  pretty disappointing. He homered on the first pitch he saw, and then went on to strike out in 42 of 95 plate appearances and batted just .189 before suffering a season-ending oblique injury in mid-September. The Yankees are hoping he can be their full-time right fielder because that job can’t possibly fall to weak-hitting Aaron Hicks.

► The Knighthawks, off to a 1-2 start in the National Lacrosse League, activated star forward Cody Jamieson Thursday and he’s expected to play Saturday night in Toronto. The Knighthawks sure missed him as they’ve scored only 28 goals in their first three games. Jamieson is trying to come back from ACL surgery, and I hope he’s not pushing his return too early. The former league MVP and three-time All-Pro ranks third all-time in team history in goals (199), assists (327) and points (526).  “I am approaching it like any other game,” Jamieson said. “I have played this game my whole life. I am always excited to get out there and run with the boys and play lacrosse.”
► If the Sabres are to make the playoffs, here's three keys:
If it were up to me …

The farcical NFL Pro Bowl would be eviscerated from our lives, permanently. I’m not breaking any new ground on this topic because it comes up every year, but the Pro Bowl is a travesty, and if not for those who still, for some unknown-to-me-reason, tune in to watch it, the game would have died long ago. Alas, football fans need their fix, even though the game is a mockery of the sport, and because it still gets ratings, the NFL won’t walk away from revenue.

The fact that the 7-9 Bills have had seven players named to the AFC roster is a clear indication of what a joke the game is. LeSean McCoy and Lorenzo Alexander deserved their spots in the original voting. Since then, due to other players dropping out for various reasons, Kyle Williams, Tyrod Taylor, Stephon Gilmore, Richie Incognito and Zach Brown have all been added to the team. No offense to any of those five players, all of whom had nice seasons, but there’s a reason they weren’t selected originally.

They were added, of course, because nearly 30 players have begged out because the Pro Bowl is the only All-Star game where players don’t really want to play. They love being picked because it helps them at contract time, but very few actually want to play in the game and risk injury. Ask Bengals tight end Tyler Eifert about that after he suffered a knee injury last year that cost him about half of this past season.

The Pro Bowl is also the only All-Star game where the players on the best teams can’t participate because they’re getting ready for the Super Bowl. That in itself should be the primary reason to end the charade. All-Star games work in MLB, the NBA, and the NHL. Because of the nature of the sport, and the timing of the game, it doesn’t work in the NFL. End it.
The numbers game
Courtesy of Elias Sports Bureau

► With his 384-yard dissection of the Steelers last Sunday, Tom Brady has now thrown for at least 300 yards against eight different teams in the postseason, two more than Peyton Manning and Kurt Warner. The Steelers have been added to a list that includes the Ravens, Broncos, Panthers, Texans, Seahawks, Raiders and Chiefs.

► As for Brady’s Super Bowl counterpart, Atlanta’s Matt Ryan, he now has 13 TD passes in his last four postseason games. Only Daryle Lamonica (1967-69) and Warner (2008-09) with 14 have thrown for more TD’s over a four-game postseason span.

► The other night, the once-mighty Los Angeles Lakers lost a game by 49 points to the Mavericks, the largest margin of defeat in franchise history. That includes the 13 seasons the team spent in Minneapolis. Just for the heck of it, I took a look at the box score for this game, and I did not recognize a single Laker name. Granted, I’m not a big follower of the NBA, but not one name rang a bell. Long, long gone are the days of Magic, Kareem, Worthy, not to mention the more recent days of Shaq and Kobe.
MAIORANA@Gannett.com

content.author: Sal Maiorana, @salmaiorana
content.headline: SalSpeak: Bills should stay clear of Chad Kelly in draft
content.description: Chad Kelly is no Jim Kelly, and the Bills would be making a mistake if they draft him.

articleBody.value: Some rebels without a clue made news twice this week when they confronted photographers who took their pictures in public, claiming that the photographers needed their permission.

The first occurred Saturday at the People's Solidarity Rally in Rochester. There, in a public park, 51-year-old Michael Hogan was taking photographs when a man in a mask marching under an anti-fascism flag approached him.
"In a loud manner, he told me I need to ask for consent to take his photos," Hogan told the police. "I told him that he was in a public place and I did not."

Later, according to video footage and Hogan’s testimony to police, six masked anti-fascists accosted Hogan and yelled obscenities at him. He shoved one of them and then got punched in the face. His assailants were arrested.
The second time occurred Monday at Rochester City Court, where the rebels were arraigned. There, associates of the rebels confronted news reporters with cameras.
"You have to ask permission to take our picture," one woman said.
"No, we don't," I said.
"Yes, you do!"
"You're in a public space; we don't need permission," replied another reporter.
"All right, then, how do you like it?" said the woman, who trained her cell phone camera and flash on me, holding it about 6 inches from me face. "How do you like it?"
I didn't answer at the time, but since she asked, not very much, thank you.
This back-and-forth spilled outside the courthouse, where more rebels snapped photos while their comrades shouted obscenities, blocked lenses and broke a microphone belonging to a television station.
So, who was right?
Hogan and the journalists were right, according to Loret Steinberg, who teaches ethics and law in photography at the Rochester Institute of Technology.

She explained that courts regard photography as akin to looking at someone or something. In other words, the camera is an extension of the person holding it. One can't stop a person from seeing in public any more than they can stop them from photographing what they see.

"To be photographed in a public place is to be seen in a public place," Steinberg said. "If you don't want to be seen, then don't go into the public place. If you don't want to be photographed in that public place, don't go there."
Of course, there are privacy laws. Courts have broken them down into four branches. None applies to the rebels.

1. "Unreasonable intrusion upon seclusion." They weren't secluded or in any place where one would expect privacy, like a bedroom or bathroom, when their photos were taken. They were in a public park and at a courthouse.

2. "Unreasonable revelation of private facts." The photos didn't reveal anything about the rebels' private lives. Perhaps one of the arrested, Cory Smith, 30, of Fairport, wore a mask to keep private the fact that he had tattooed a spider and buffalo on his face. I know I would. But police had him take his mask off in public.

3. "Unreasonably placing another person in a false light." A photo that accurately depicts a situation that occurred in public won't support a false light claim, even if the person pictured is offended by the image.
4. "Misappropriation of a person's likeness for commercial gain." This doesn’t apply, although some might argue that news outlets gain financially by publishing photos.

In that case, the law falls to a landmark case known as Arrington v. The New York Times, in which a man sued The Times after a photo of him taken in public was used to illustrate a story with which he did not agree. The courts ruled that The Times's First Amendment rights trumped the man's privacy rights.
"If something is newsworthy, it trumps everything," Steinberg said.
But what about etiquette? Isn't it common courtesy to ask permission to take someone's photo? Steinberg urges her students to weigh the importance of a photo against any objections of the subject.

If her students were assigned to capture images of spring, for instance, and a mother objected to her child being photographed playing in a field of daffodils, Steinberg asks her students to consider whether there is any other way to capture spring than risk offending the mother. In that case, there would be.

In the case of the rebels without a clue, what other way could there have been to capture masked anti-fascists at a public demonstration and at a courthouse after their arraignment than to take their photo?
David Andreatta is a Democrat and Chronicle columnist. He can be reached at dandreatta@gannett.com.

content.author: David Andreatta, @david_andreatta

content.description: Yes, anyone can take a photo of someone in a public place. No, they don't need permission.

articleBody.value: Richard Leon Wilbern, accused of the 2003 robbery and murder at the Xerox credit union, pleaded not guilty to the charges Friday.

Wilbern was arrested in September after a former Xerox employee told police he recognized him from enhanced photos and videos from the credit union. Authorities say Wilbern's DNA largely matches that found on an umbrella left behind by the killer-robber.
This week, a federal grand jury indicted Wilbern for the robbery and killing, as well as for separate gun possession charges.
Originally, Wilbern was scheduled to be in court Friday for a bail hearing. However, that hearing is now set for Feb. 15.

Two Xerox employees who were in the Xerox Federal Credit Union to transact business were shot during the  the robbery. Raymond Batzel was struck in the head and later pronounced dead at the scene. Joseph Doud was shot in the shoulder but survived.
GCRAIG@Gannett.com

content.author: Gary Craig, @gcraig1

articleBody.value: It's one of the most popular areas for retail in our region. And now, a TJ Maxx store will open in Victor.

Plans are underway for the discount retailer to open at the former Office Max space at Cobblestone Court, across from Eastview Mall, said Joseph A. Fiorie, president of NAI Fiorie, a Perinton-based real estate brokerage firm. The area along route 96 in Victor is among the most desirable in the region due to the proximity to the high-end mall as well as the demographics of shoppers, he said.

Cobblestone Court is home to large and small businesses, from Kmart and Dick's Sporting Goods to eateries like Umi and Moe's Southwest Grill. The recently closed Half Moon Salads at 2900 Monroe Ave. will open a location next to Moe's, Fiorie said. Opening dates for both new retailers have not yet been determined.

I've always wondered why there isn't a TJ Maxx or Marshalls in the Victor area as it has become the go to place for shopping. Discount retailers such as TJ Maxx and Marshalls are among the few growth areas in brick and mortar retail, the other being outlet shopping, which The Marketplace Mall in Henrietta is in the process of transitioning to. There is a HomeGoods in Victor at Victor Crossing plaza near the Walmart. HomeGoods is also owned by the TJX family of companies and sells home furnishings and decor at discount prices. With prices easily accessible through a google search on a smart phone, consumers are now much more savvy about discount shopping.
New steak house in Victor
Past the village in Victor, Meat & Tomottos has opened at 200 Phoenix Mills Plaza, on Route 96 across from Auction Direct.

The restaurant is the brainchild of chef and owner Tim Archetko, who opened Otto Tomottos 12 years ago. Otto Tomottos moved to a larger space at 300 Phoenix Mills Plaza last year and the old spot was renovated into a swanky new steak house.

While his original restaurant is more casual, Meat & Tomottos has a decidedly upscale feel from the ambiance to service to the presentation of the food. We enjoyed dinner there with a large group of eight, sampling appetizers and desserts. Even when I'm not at an Asian restaurant, I like to dine Asian family style, which is to sample a little bit of everything.

I don't like to waste and over eat, so sampling appetizers like calamari and crab cake meant sharing an entree with my husband, selecting the hanger steak — wet-aged — with a side of pumpkin quinoa for $25. The waitress was kind enough to split the portion on two plates and it was more than enough for two, with leftovers to take home. Steak is the one item I cannot prepare well at home, no matter how I try. I've purchased dry rub seasonings, marinated the meat, shopped at prime meat markets and cooked them on the manly grill to no avail. Alas, I will head out to restaurants when I have a hankering for steak, the exception being the Korean thin steak bulgolgi, which is pretty easy to master.
Plum Bistro closes suddenly
It didn't even last a year. Plum Bistro at Village Gate has closed after opening this past summer. Thanks to reader Carol Schaubroeck for tipping me off.

Plum Bistro took the place of the former Dark Horse Coffee at Village Gate. It had opened as Plum House Cafe that offered a cafeteria style of fast casual bowls from ramen noodles to rice with choice of meats and vegetables. It shifted to Plum Bistro in November, a more formal Asian fusion style restaurant.
A new Asian restaurant will take the place of the now closed Plum Bistro.
Jos A. Bank in Brighton closes
Joseph A. Bank Clothiers, Inc., also known by JoS. A. Bank,  has closed its Brighton location at Tops Plaza, 1900 S. Clinton Ave. Customers are being redirected to its Pittsford Plaza store.

The retailer is known for its affordable men's suits and is owned by Men's Warehouse. Established in 1905, it sells its products in over 800 stores throughout the country. The retailer was mentioned in the corruption trial of former Virginia Governor Bob McDonnell. "Jos. A. Bank is where I usually go," the former governor said.
With Rochester being home base to Hickey Freeman, I wonder if the regular warehouse sales hurt retail menswear business, especially for shoppers who are cost conscious.

Matt McDermott, owner of Vittorio Menswear & Tuxedo in Irondequoit, offers this thought about Hickey Freeman: "I've always wanted to carry their stuff, but it's hard to sell their suit for $1,200 like Nordstrom does when they sell it in their back yard at big markdowns."
Introducing the other half

Many thanks to the Women of Rotary for inviting me to speak at their monthly luncheon. Several ladies asked about my teen daughter, Noelle Nafus, and had wanted to meet her. She is the silent half of the Comings and Goings column, dishing her views on our mother daughter outings to find new stores and restaurants.
A foodie fashionista, she started her tween blog on fashion in fifth grade, but has moved on to producing YouTube videos on fashion, food and decor since blogs are oh, so, 2010.

Mary Chao is the retail and real estate reporter at Democrat and Chronicle Media Group. E-mail tips to mchao@Gannett.com. Follow her on Twitter and Instagram @marychaostyle and on Facebook @MaryChaoRochester
Bargain of the week

One of the hottest fashion accessories in the past year is the comeback of shawls and ponchos. They're a steal of a deal at NTY Clothing Exchange at 3005 Monroe Ave. in Pittsford, with prices ranging from $12 to $18 in myriad patterns and colors. They're great year-round and in the cold winter season they double as a scarf or may be draped over a coat.

NTY is a resale store, but it carries new inventory as well. Shawls, socks, leggings and some jewelry are brand new. Consignment and resale stores are not for everyone. My husband with his Jan Brady, middle child, hand me down issues, would never shop at one and doesn't like it when we do.

But me and my daughter are frugal fashionistas. And we scored big at NTY as it was in the midst of a clearance sale, 75 percent off its low resale prices. I should say she scored big because she is a size zero, extra small, and this is where the thin and rich women drop off their clothes for resale. Many of the items are new with tags and have never been worn.

While the shop has your typically upper middle brands like Uggs and Michael Kors, if you dig and you know your fashion, you will find treasures. My daughter religiously follows fashion on Instagram and magazines and knew exactly what's hot. It's like going to an antique store with a dealer.

Some of the finds include include a new Wildfox Couture sweater for $6 and a free people sweater for $4. We found other couture brands such as a Pink Tartan dress that would retail for $300 for $5, a Carmen Marc Valvo dress for $7 that usually runs around $400, plus brands such as Alice +Olivia and Brandy Melville. The clearance sale is over, but its regular resale prices could still save you up to 80 percent off retail. The styles at NTY are more youthful trendy--not really my taste or my size as I prefer European lagenlook brands like Lilith, which I can find at Panache Vintage and Finer Consignments in Brighton, or the upscale comfortable Eileen Fisher, which I can find on consignment at Lu's Back Door in Fairport. The owner did send me to check out her other shops called Clothes Mentor in Henrietta and Greece and I stopped in Henrietta, finding mostly mall and department store brands like Ann Taylor and Tahari. The demographics of the location of the shop often determine the resale inventory.

Back to NTY, my daughter's keen sense of fashion landed us one of the greatest bargains of all: a $600 pair of Red Valentino pumps on clearance for $16. Twitter follower @PittsfordDad questioned how shoes could cost $600. My response is that people buy prestige through material goods, whether $600 shoes or a $60,000 car. I would never spend that much on either. Which means my daughter will wear those Valentino pumps to her wedding.

articleBody.value: Before he planned to attack patrons at a Rochester bar in an Islamic State-inspired crime,  Emanuel Lutchman had another plot: He would kill his wife.
The FBI had not planned to arrest Lutchman on Dec. 30, 2015, when it did — a day before Lutchman intended to wield a machete and attack New Year's Eve patrons at a Rochester bar.

But agents learned that Lutchman had told an FBI informant that he wanted to kill his wife — Lutchman had earlier been convicted of menacing her — and agents believed they had to intervene for the woman's safety.

"We were getting worried that he was taking serious steps" to find his wife, FBI Special Agent Joseph Testani said Thursday, after Lutchman was sentenced to 20 years for conspiring to assist the terrorist organization, the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, or ISIL.

On Thursday, U.S.District Judge Frank Geraci Jr. sentenced Lutchman, 26, to the maximum sentence of 20 years. Only moments before, Lutchman had tearfully apologized to the court and his family. He said he had renounced ISIL and its plans to violently establish a caliphate in the Middle East.
But once Geraci imposed the sentence, Lutchman turned angry and defiant.
"You think because I'm going to be incarcerated there aren't going to be more of us that rise up," Lutchman said, his voice rising.
Geraci responded calmly, saying that Lutchman apparently still adhered to ISIL's tenets, despite his assertions to the contrary.
"Yes I do," Lutchman answered. "… There's going to be more of us."

For prosecutors and police, the outburst was evidence of Lutchman's danger. A man who has struggled with mental illness for much of his life, Lutchman has been portrayed by family and supporters as a fragile individual who was duped into the terrorist plot by an FBI informant.
But Lutchman's anger, which included shouts and rants in Arabic, were proof of his "true colors," said Assistant U.S. Attorney Brett Harvey, the prosecutor in the case.
At Lutchman's sentencing Thursday, Harvey detailed how Lutchman had initiated contact with a Syria-based ISIL recruiter, who directed Lutchman to commit a crime on U.S. soil.

A felon who'd been imprisoned for robbery, Lutchman could not buy a gun. So he decided to attack the patrons at Merchants Grill in Rochester with a machete and knives, and possibly take some hostage, authorities say.
"He's a zealous and ardent supporter of the Islamic State," Harvey said.

Lutchman recorded a video in which he told of his planned New Year's Eve assault. He'd been told to create the video by the recruiter for ISIL, and the Islamic State aimed to use it for propaganda, Harvey said.
At sentencing, Lutchman's attorney,  Assistant Federal Public Defender Steven Slawinski, highlighted Lutchman's mental health problems, including bipolar disorder, depression and suicidal ideations.

Lutchman, who often panhandled in the same neighborhood as the Merchants Grill, was so destitute that the FBI informant accompanied him to Walmart on Dec. 29, 2015, and spent $40 to buy the machete, knives and zip ties that Lutchman intended to use in his attack.
"The risk of danger here is exaggerated by the government," said Slawinski, who had argued in court papers for a 10-year sentence for Lutchman.

Lutchman's anger toward his wife was not mentioned in court, or in court papers. But, in an interview after the sentencing, FBI agent Testani said law enforcement arrested him when they did because of Lutchman's comments that he wanted to seek out his wife and kill her.
The wife, who has a 2-year-old son with Lutchman, had an order of protection against him.

The FBI and other members of the regional Joint Terrorism Task Force were preparing the legal papers to arrest Lutchman and head off the New Year's Eve plot when they learned that he'd told the informant of his murderous intentions toward his wife.
"We sent out agents to find her," said Testani.
The informant, who had been working with the FBI, was able to connect with Lutchman. Agents arrested Lutchman in a car with the informant.
Lutchman was "intent on doing it ... and irrational," Testani said of Lutchman's desire to kill his wife.
Lutchman pleaded guilty in August to providing "material support" to a terrorist organization —  a sweeping law designed to battle terrorism in the United States.
In court Thursday, Judge Geraci acknowledged Lutchman's mental struggles, but said that same psychological fragility "also created a real danger in this community."
Lutchman's ISIL-motivated video, in which he told how he intended to attack the Merchants Grill, was proof of his seriousness to carry out the crime, Geraci said.
"That video ... indicates that this was the real deal," Geraci said. "People were going to die at the Merchant's Grill on New Year's Eve, but for the intervention of law enforcement."
As U.S. Marshals Service deputies removed Lutchman from court after his eruption, he shouted back at Geraci, "(Expletive) you!"
An unfazed Geraci responded, "Motion denied."
GCRAIG@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: A tiny local development corporation formed back in 2015 to help get eight vacant houses near a Superfund site in Holley, Orleans County back on the tax rolls is concerned that an edict from the Trump administration that freezes all grants and contracts by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, could create additional delays for their effort.

At issue are eight houses left vacant since January 2002, when a number of village residents fled an accidental chemical release at the former Diaz Chemical Corp. on Jackson Street. That spill set off a chain reaction that led within two years to the company's bankruptcy and the Diaz facility being named by EPA to the list of the nation's worst toxic waste sites. Holley is located about 25 miles west of Rochester.
►Holley homes near chemical spill getting new life

While EPA has always said the homes are safe, residents refused to return to them, leading the agency in 2005 to spend $1.3 million buying the houses and relocating the residents. EPA has since performed basic maintenance, kept the grass cut and kept the heat and power on so the pipes wouldn't freeze.
The agency signed a memorandum of understanding back in September enabling transfer to the Holley Development Corp.
Dan Schiavone, that group's president, said transfer of the properties had been imminent. His group intends to put the houses back on the market as soon as possible.
"If this does impede our progress, we will be very disappointed," he said.

Also unclear after the Trump administration's action is the status of the planned $14.5 million long-term cleanup plan for the site. That plan entails using electrodes to heat the ground in six contaminated areas. Steam driven out of the soil would carry out the contaminants and the resulting vapor would be collected and cleaned.
Already, EPA crews removed more than 9,000 drums of chemicals, 112,000 gallons of hazardous waste, 9.6 linear miles of waste-filled piping and 3,100 tons of contaminated concrete from the Diaz site.

U.S. Senator Charles Schumer, D-New York, on Thursday demanded the agency confirm that the freeze would not stall or reverse the EPA's long-awaited transfer of eight houses in Holley over to the Village of Holley Development Corporation.

"It’s unconscionable that at the 11th hour, this new, short-sighted EPA policy could jeopardize years of work by the Village of Holley to acquire the 'Diaz 8' vacant homes from the EPA," Schumer said in written statements. "A promise is a promise and the signed Memorandum of Agreement says the EPA must- and without any delay fulfill its obligation to the Village of Holley and complete this critical transfer."
Other projects
In terms of other projects in New York, state officials have had limited comment on the freeze and rumored EPA reductions.

"New York is closely monitoring all actions by the new administration and impacts on funding for vital New York programs.  We will continue to work with the federal government and our partners on every level to ensure that our environment and public health are protected,” said a joint statement provided by the departments of health and environmental conservation.
It was not clear what EPA grants or contracts the two state agencies hold.

Locally, neither the University of Rochester nor Rochester Institute of Technology receive substantial amounts of grant money from the federal agency, spokespersons at the two universities reported this week.

One EPA funding stream that would be of concern in upstate New York is the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative, an Obama-administration program that has provided $650 million since 2010 for research, remediation and improvements on and near the five Great Lakes. Most of the 850 grants have gone to state agencies, municipalities, universities and non-profit groups.
About 120 GLRI projects valued at $124 million remain active, according to the latest GLRI data.
Of that total, nine projects valued at nearly $8 million are focused on New York.

Monroe County has a small grant to help with the study of pollutants in the lower Genesee River and nearby waters of Lake Ontario, and Ducks Unlimited is just concluding $500,000 worth of invasive species control work at Braddock Bay.

One of the largest grants in New York, $1.3 million, was given to Clarkson University in St. Lawrence County to pay for continued development of new techniques to monitor toxic-chemical contamination of Great Lakes fish. The grant is to run through 2020.
Michael Griffin, a spokesman for the university, said earlier this week that “we  really don’t have any additional information at this point. We really don’t know what the freeze means.”
MCDERMOT@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: A Rochester police gambling raid led to an arrest on weapons and drug charges but, as of yet, no gambling-related charges, police say.
On Friday, Jan. 20, police raided a suspected gambling operation at a vacant building at 380/384 W. Ridge Road.
Arrested was Daniel Elliott, a 53-year-old Gates resident, who is accused of illegal weapons possession, a felony, and misdemeanor possession of cocaine and marijuana.
Elliott's attorney, Vincent Merante, said Elliott did not possess the two handguns. Court documents say they were in a kitchen cabinet and Elliott had keys to the cabinet.
Merante said he has yet to see the search warrant for the raid.
"There were approximately 25 people in the place" when raided, he said.
Rochester police acknowledged that the bust was part of a gambling investigation. Elliott was the only arrest.
He denies the weapons and drug possession charges, Merante said.
GCRAIG@Gannett.com

content.author: Gary Craig, @gcraig1

articleBody.value: Norm Lewis, who made history in May 2014 as The Phantom of the Opera’s first African-American Phantom on Broadway, brings Norm Lewis: The Music of the Night to Kodak Hall at the Eastman Theatre at 8 p.m. Friday, Jan. 27. Tickets to see Lewis — who also received Tony, Drama Desk, Drama League and Outer Critics Circle award nominations for his work in The Gershwins’ Porgy & Bess — are $20 to $65. Go to eastmantheatre.org or call (585) 274-3000.
The Rochester Americans face off against the Albany Devils at 7:05 p.m. Friday, Jan. 27, at Blue Cross Arena at the Community War Memorial. Tickets are $12 to $26. Go to ticketmaster.com.

A Magical Journey Thru Stages presents Footloose, the Musical — based on the immensely popular 1984 movie about a small town where rock and roll and dancing are forbidden — from Friday, Jan. 27, through Sunday, Feb. 5, at the STAGES Theater, on the third floor of the Auditorium Center. Tickets are $13 ($10 in advance). Go to mjtstages.com or call (585) 935-7173.

Winterfest — with activities for children, a bonfire/marshmallow roast, craft vendors, ice skating (depending on the weather) and more — runs from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 28, at the Irondequoit Town Hall campus on Titus Avenue. Admission is free. Go to irondequoit.org/irondequoit-events.

Honoring the band’s late founder, Tony Cavagnaro, The Buddhahood and Friends’ 9th annual January Thaw Tribute Concert is set for 7 p.m. Saturday, Jan. 28, at Anthology in the upper East End. Also on the bill: Extended Family and Bombshell Belly Dance. Proceeds go to the Tony Cavagnaro Young Musicians Scholarship Fund. Tickets are $12 ($10 in advance). Go to anthologylive.com or call (585) 484-1964.

The Rochester RazorSharks take on the Jamestown Jackals at 2 p.m. Sunday, Jan. 29, at Blue Cross Arena at the Community War Memorial. Tickets are $5 to $25; free for children 12 and younger with the purchase of an adult ticket. Go to razorsharks.com or call (585) 232-9190.

Indiana-bred groove outfit Umphrey’s McGee headlines a Sunday, Jan. 29, show at Anthology. Opening are saxophonist Joshua Redman and jam band Spafford. Tickets are $27.50 to $30. Go to anthologylive.com or call (585) 423-1931.

Emancipation Denied: The Story of Black Wall Street is being staged by the North Star Players through Saturday, Jan. 28, at MuCCC. Set in the early 1900s, the play (written by Rochester’s Deborah Solomon) tells of the hopes, struggles and successes of an African-American community in Tulsa, Oklahoma, dubbed “Black Wall Street” by Booker T. Washington because of its economic opportunities. Tickets are $7 to $15. To buy them, and for show times, go to muccc.org/events.

articleBody.value: The Rochester Americans will host “Hometown Heroes Night” on Friday, Jan. 27 when the team hosts the Albany Devils in a 7:05 p.m. game at the Blue Cross Arena at the Community War Memorial.

This annual event holds special significance for nearly a dozen Amerks and staff, whose family members are police officers, fire fighters, first responders, emergency medical technicians, as well as military members and veterans.
► No worries with Ullmark in net
To kick off the night, the Rochester Police Department will face off against the Monroe County Sheriff's Office Jail Bureau in an exhibition starting at 4 p.m..

The club if offering one complimentary ticket to all Hometown Heroes and military personnel, plus family and friends can purchase tickets for as low as $12. For every ticket sold $2 will be donated to the Monroe County Sheriff's Office Association of Retirees, courtesy of event sponsor Advantage Federal Credit Union. Tickets can be purchased at amerks.com/hero and Hometown Heroes and their families can submit photos that will be shown on the video board during the game.
Amerks with Hometown Heroes connections
Police
Tim Kennedy: Father and grandfather were officers along with several of his uncles;
Cole Schneider: Friend is a police officer in Buffalo;
John Muse: Cousin is a city police officer in Boston;
Jean Dupuy: Brother is currently pursuing a career in law enforcement
Daniel Muzito-Bagenda: Brother-in-law’s father is an officer
Fire
Brycen Martin: Father is a fire captain in Calgary;
Cole Schneider: Cousin is a fire fighter;
Bobby Shea: Brother-in-law is a fire fighter;
Vaclav Karabacek: Cousin is a fire fighter in the Czech Republic;
Assistant Coach Cuck Weber: Coached team of fire fighters while in Orlando

articleBody.value: Trucks and vans drive through Pittsford village, often under cover of darkness. They stop at the Saint’s Place’s donation drop-off site and then drive off, leaving the refugee resettlement charity a little poorer.
Technically, these thieves don’t “steal.” Rather they cart in their own junk and leave it for the charity to deal with. The effect is the same.

Each truckload of garbage — cracked aquariums, mildewed couches, stained rugs, broken dressers —  costs Saint’s Place about $150 to dispose of. Typically the non-profit accumulates a truckload of donated junk per month. So much unusable stuff has been piling up recently, the charity can find itself doing a “dump run” every two weeks.
► More Eric Bryant columns

Director Michele Quinn tries to look at unusable donations, like a stethoscope, with a sense of humor. “We had a lot of Cuban doctors come in last year, maybe one of them could use it,” Quinn said. “Every time I turn around, there is something to make you laugh.”

A stethoscope, at least, is small. Not so for the tattered and gigantic corner sectional that turned up one morning this week. It would take up most of the floor space in a refugee’s humble apartment. Plus it was not in good condition, so volunteers had to cart this very heavy piece of furniture to the dump and pay for its disposal.

Quinn stresses that Saint’s Place is extremely grateful for donations of clean, gently used items. Last year it used them to furnish homes for 1250 refugees who have fled danger, arriving in Rochester with little more than the clothes they are wearing. Saint's Place wish list includes clean clothing, furniture, lamps, small appliances, linens, pots, pans, dishes and children’s toys. Saint’s Place volunteers are happy to go to homes and pick up heavy furniture for donation.

Too often people dump huge items when no one is around — possibly because they are embarrassed to have anyone see that they are “donating” couches with no springs, broken dressers and damaged office furniture.
“On the weekends people just leave it in our backyard,” Quinn said. “It doesn’t help us accomplish our mission and takes a lot of extra volunteer hours to deal with.”

Saint’s Place simply will not give refugees anything that is broken or dirty. Volunteers do not have the time to find new drawers, handles and feet for a broken dresser. It would be nice to have a furniture refurbishing center one day, said Quinn. For now Saint’s Place’s hands are full and broken furniture is simply a burden.

When in doubt, it is best to ask if a large item will be useful to a charity before donating it. The Community Wishbook at www.communitywishbook.org has a list of charities and their wish lists to help people find the best place for their donations.
Sometimes stuff just needs to be thrown away. Don’t make a charity do your dirty work.
Erica Bryant is the Pay It Forward columnist. Contact her at ebryant@gannett.com

content.author: Erica Bryant, @Erica_Bryant_

articleBody.value: The annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is a showcase for the newest cutting edge products from the world's top technology companies.
But for Eastman Kodak Co., this year's showcase was a nod to the past.
The company showed off a new Super 8 movie camera, announced it was bringing back Ektachrome film, and even hinted at the possible revival of the beloved Kodachrome brand.

It has been five years since the film giant filed for bankruptcy, the inevitable result of a shift in consumer behavior.  The proliferation of digital cameras and online photo sharing caused film sales to plummet. In the span of a decade, the Kodak products that long held a dominant space on every retailer's shelves disappeared from the marketplace.

Why now?  What's happened during the past five years to spark a resurgence of interest in analog technologies as the world grows increasingly digital? Is it simply a nod to nostalgia, or is there a sustainable business here?
Super 8 and the Hollywood connection
Appearing on a company podcast called "The Kodakery," chief marketing officer Steven Overman said the decision to bring back Ektachrome was an easy one.

"We get asked all the time by filmmakers and photographers alike, 'Are you going to bring back some of these iconic film stocks like Kodachrome and Ektachrome?'" he said. "I will say we are investigating Kodachrome, looking at what it would take to bring that back. Ektachrome is a lot easier and faster to bring back to market."

One of the challenges lies in the complexity of Kodachrome. The manufacturing process is complicated, but making the film itself is just one piece of the puzzle.  Reviving Kodachrome would require the re-creation of an entire ecosystem, including labs that could process the film and produce prints or slides to deliver to the consumer.
It's a daunting task, but that's what's happening with the Super 8.
When you buy a film cartridge for your new Super 8 camera, you're paying for development, processing, scanning and uploading a digital version to the cloud. It's all included as part of the package.
The business model hearkens back to George Eastman's early advertising slogan: "You press the button, we do the rest."

Kodak introduced the concept of "home movies" when Super 8 cameras hit the market in 1965. A generation of amateur filmmakers followed, some of whom became Hollywood legends. Steven Spielberg, George Lucas and Martin Scorsese all got their start shooting 8mm film as teenagers.
But even younger directors who grew up during the camcorder era say that the Super 8 film cameras were what helped propel them toward a career in filmmaking.

"The news that Kodak is enabling the next generation of filmmakers with access to an upgraded and enhanced version of the same analog technology that first made me fall in love with cinematic storytelling is unbelievably exciting," said Christopher Nolan, whose directing credits include Inception and The Dark Knight.
Writer and director J.J. Abrams also expressed his excitement at Kodak's announcement.
"While any technology that allows for visual storytelling must be embraced, nothing beats film." Abrams said. "The fact that Kodak is building a brand new Super 8 camera is a dream come true."
Kodak CEO Jeff Clarke says the commitment to film is about enabling young filmmakers to explore the craft and an affordable and accessible way.

"There are Super 8 cameras you can buy on eBay that still work really well, and enthusiasts do that," Clarke said. "But we want young filmmakers, film schools, and people who want to be a little different to be able to participate in film. Not everyone has a budget like Steven Spielberg or Christopher Nolan or Quentin Tarantino. The Super 8 camera becomes a gateway for people who care about film and want to have a differentiated  product around photography."
Don't take my Kodachrome away
That same excitement has greeted news about the return of Ektachrome film, and even the possibility of Kodachrome returning.

Willie Osterman, a photography professor at the Rochester Institute of Technology and chair of the school's fine art photography program, says that while digital cameras makes it easier for an amateur to take pictures, the unique qualities of film are still appealing to professional photographers.

"In the art world, photographers prefer film because of what it's able to produce. There's something about that quality of grain that helps aesthetically," he says. "It's subtle, but at a certain level you appreciate that."

While there were once a hundred darkrooms for students at RIT to work in, now there are fewer than 30.  Most have been converted to digital editing bays, and freshmen are no longer required to take a course in processing black and white prints from film.

Osterman says digital photography has prompted an amazing revolution. But for visual professionals it's simply a different medium, not one that replaces film.  Each offers its own unique attributes, in the way that a painter might choose between working with acrylic or oils.

"There is a color palette that Kodachrome and Ektachrome have," he said. "Kodachrome is richer in warm colors. Ektachrome is cooler, with more blues. Depending on where and what I was photographing, I would choose a film because of the color palette it produced."

During his podcast appearance, Kodak's chief marketing officer said that the Super 8 and Ektachrome revivals were driven by consumer demand, and that the company heard a clamoring for more of these products.

"Ektachrome is not the last thing we are going to bring back," Overman said. "We are going to continue to identify those products that the world is hungry for and we're going to do everything we can to keep delivering them."
Hands-on experience

The average consumer got rid of their Instamatic or inexpensive 35 mm camera as the digital age dawned.  Whether they replaced it with a digital camera or simply used their smartphone to capture pictures, they didn't mind leaving the analog process behind.

But for many, the passion for traditional photography remained — the method of capturing images on film, processing that film, and producing prints on photographic paper. For them, the prospect of these Kodak products returning is tantalizing.
"There is a culture of people that are trembling with excitement," says Mark Osterman, process historian at the George Eastman Museum. "I think it's great."

He leads workshops in photographic processing for the museum, including many methods that have fallen out of use.  He says there's been a huge resurgence in interest in these techniques for fine arts photography.
"Last year we had 23 workshops on old photographic processes like tintypes, glass negatives, daguerreotypes, and 35 mm motion picture film." says Mark Osterman, who is not related to Willie Osterman.
As soon as those workshops are announced, the registration lists are filled to capacity.  People travel from all over the country and even from Europe just to participate.

What it shows, Mark Osterman says, is a desire for a hands-on experience, to actually make something with one's own hands.  In the digital world, the photographer is detached from the process of making pictures.  The push of a button creates an image file. The push of another button sends that image into the cloud for others to see.  There's a level of detachment, a lack of deliberateness in the digital workflow.

It's very different from the resurgence of vinyl records for listening to music, he says.  While those record albums provide a more tactile process for listening to music, re-creating the process is not as challenging. You could build a record press in your garage and figure out how to capture sound onto discs.
Color film, on the other hand, is incredibly complex, not the sort of thing a person could learn to manufacture or process on his or her own.

"Chromogenic color film is the most technologically advanced product ever sold to the consumer. It's more difficult to make than an automobile or a computer," Mark Osterman says. "If Kodak were to decide not to make any color film and discarded those manufacturing machines, the world would never see color film again."
The brain trust of people who know the chemistry of color photography are in their twilight years, he says.
Mark Osterman believes this is perhaps what's most important about Kodak's announcement, that it hints at a long-term plan not just for Kodak but for preserving the future of film.
"They are doing what they need to do to keep it possible to produce a technically challenging product," he says.
Future of film business
Speaking at the Consumer Electronics Show, Clarke said the return of the Super 8 camera should send a clear message about Kodak's intention to make a strong return to the world of consumer products.

"It's a symbol of what Kodak cares about and our commitment to film," Clarke said at the show. "Even though the business now is focused on printing and other advanced technologies, film is still core to our company.  It's about 10 percent of our revenue, and its profitable."
So, is the return to film a nod to nostalgia or is there a sustainable business here?
"The answer to both questions is yes," says George Conboy, chairman of Brighton Securities.
He says there's clearly a consumer demand for photographic film, just as there is a market for greeting cards in a world of email.
"The return of Ektachrome and the idea of Super 8 will appeal to people in what I'd call the fine art space and to those with a hipster sensibility," Conboy says.

Kodak was selling a couple of billion rolls of film each year at its peak, and it won't need to reach anywhere near those volumes for this renewed effort to be successful. We're not going to see the return of film as a mass market consumer product.
"The business is not huge but neither is Kodak anymore. If they can make a profit, more power to them," Conboy says.

It's not likely that Kodak Park is going to rumble back to life, or that the resurgence of film will lead to hundreds of new jobs returning to Kodak. But Kodak has an advantage in terms of both the institutional knowledge and the infrastructure. Former competitors like FujiFilm and Agfa aren't capable of getting back into the film business.
Conboy says the moves show an encouraging shift in Kodak's strategy.
"Management is attempting to be nimble, to seek out revenue and profits in any venue they can," he says.
As an avid photographer, Conboy would love to see Kodachrome return. But as a business analyst, he's skeptical.
"There were never more than a few labs in the country that could process that film," he says. "My prediction is there won't be enough volume to make that work."
SLAHMAN@Gannett.com
► Kodak making big push at '17 Consumer Electronics Show
► Smaller Kodak posts $12M profit in 3Q
► 'Star Wars' a tribute to Kodak film
And because it's in your head by now ...

content.shortHeadline: A comeback for Kodachrome?
content.about: The annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is a showcase for the newest cutting edge products from the world's top technology companies.But for Eastman Kodak Co., this year's showcase was a nod to the past.The company showed off a new Super 8 movie camera, announced it was bringing back Ektachrome film, and even hinted at the possible revival of the beloved Kodachrome brand.It has been five years since the film giant filed for bankruptcy, the inevitable result of a shift in consumer behavior. The proliferation of digital cameras and online photo sharing caused film sales to plummet. In the span of a decade, the Kodak products that long held a dominant space on every retailer's shelves disappeared from the marketplace.

articleBody.value: All patient rooms at Rochester General Hospital will become private after an expansion and renovation project on its Portland Avenue campus.

The state Department of Health on Thursday moved the project closer to reality when a committee recommended approval of a seven-story building on the northeast side of the existing hospital. According to documents filed by Rochester General and its parent organization, Rochester Regional Health, the project is expected to cost about $253.7 million.
Rochester General still has to submit drawings of the site for state approval and has to pay fees and submit a bond resolution.
The full Public Health and Health Planning Council is scheduled to vote on the project Feb. 9.

"If we receive approval from the Council in February, there is only one step remaining — getting a certificate of need from the New York State Department of Health," Hugh Thomas, chief administration officer and general counsel for Rochester Regional, wrote in a statement. "If we do get approval for the CON, work on the seven-story, 312,000 square-foot critical care center will begin by the end of the second quarter."
The project is expected to take several years.
The Finger Lakes Health Systems Agency, which uses data to improve health outcomes in a nine-county region, has recommended that the state approve the project.

“General has been an old hospital for a number of years now,” said Dr. Thomas Mahoney, chief medical officer of the Finger Lakes Health Systems Agency. “This will move them (Rochester General) up and be more consistent with current best practice.”

The hospital will remain at 528 beds, but all will be in private rooms. Currently, fewer than half the rooms are single-occupancy. Having single rooms gives a hospital more flexibility by eliminating the need to assign rooms based on gender or the seriousness of a patient’s condition. Single rooms also are viewed in the health care industry as a way to reduce infection.

To compare, UR Medicine's Strong Memorial Hospital has 320 private medical/surgical and intensive care rooms and 220 semi-private rooms. At UR Medicine's Highland Hospital, there are 93 private medical/surgical 14 ICU rooms.
After the project, RGH will have the same number of operating rooms. Three will remain in the current building.
According to documents filed by Rochester General with the state, the new building will encompass 312,457 square feet. Among other services, it will contain:

• 108 medical/surgical and intensive care unit rooms;
  • a 14-bed neonatal unit;
  • 20 private post-partum rooms;
  • 20 replacement operating rooms; and
  • 54 pre- and post-op patient areas.

The renovation of the existing hospital includes turning 108 semi-private rooms into private rooms, moving the observation unit into the current intensive care/coronary care unit and finding a new use for part of the operating room suite.
The RGH project exceeds the scale of some other recent hospital makeovers.

• In 2016, UR Medicine completed a $28 million, two-story addition at Highland Hospital with six new operating rooms and a 26-bed observation unit.
  • In 2015, UR Medicine completed the $145 million, eight-story Golisano Children’s Hospital.
  • In 2014, Unity completed a $180 million expansion that included larger, all-private rooms and the Charles J. August Joint Replacement Center and Golisano Restorative Neurology & Rehabilitation Center. At the time, Unity was independent. It now is part of Rochester Regional Health.

According to documents filed by RGH with the state, staffing is expected to increase by about 58 full-time equivalents in the first year of the completed project, and remain at that level through the third year.

The project will be financed by about $102.3 million in equity and about $151.3 million in tax-exempt fixed-rate bonds at 4.27 percent interest for 30 years. According to the operating budget filed with the application for the project, inpatient revenue is expected to increase in the first year after the project is completed.
PSINGER@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: With a father who could play hundreds of songs on the harmonica, the DuPre family of Penfield enjoyed an interesting and entertaining upbringing.
“Oh yes,’’ Mary Ann DuPre said. “We had great campfires.’’
At 93, Peter DuPre’s fire is still burning bright, his soulful notes reaching an audience larger than his wildest dreams.
A medic during World War II who treated the wounded from the Battle of the Bulge, Peter DuPre always enjoyed playing his harmonica for his family, his church congregation and at nursing homes.

But since Jane, his wife of 70 years, passed away three years ago at age 90, and since becoming involved in The Greatest Generations Foundation which honors veterans for their service, DuPre has performed at major military memorial services in Europe and the United States before thousands.

Those include the 70th anniversary of Bastogne and the 74th and 75th commemorations of Pearl Harbor where DuPre’s chilling rendition of America The Beautiful standing alone inside the USS Arizona Memorial has been widely shared on social media.

Last February, DuPre, thanks to Greatest Generation Foundation benefactors, even traveled to Nashville to record an album of 40 pop hits, from Glenn Miller to Billy Joel, at famed Paragon Studios that is due to be released this spring. The Fairport resident is featured on The Greatest Generations Foundation website and can be found on Facebook pictured with country music superstars Garth Brooks and Trisha Yearwood at a Los Angeles gala.
And now the man dubbed “Harmonica Pete’’ is branching into sports.

Fresh off performing the national anthem at the Pearl Harbor Invitational NCAA basketball game between Cal and Seton Hall in December at historic Bloch Arena that withstood the Japanese attack of Dec. 7, 1941, and after receiving a standing ovation at a recent Rochester Americans game where he was presented with a No. 93 jersey, DuPre has been invited by the National Hockey League to perform the anthem at a Florida Panthers game in Sunrise, Florida, sometime next month.
His family may need to hire him a full-time secretary.

“I think it’s neat. I’m part ham, I love to tell stories and I have no trouble saying yes,’’ said DuPre as he sat near the veterans memorial eternal flame at Blue Cross Arena. “I’ve been very fortunate in my life to be in the right place at the right time and as a result of that I’ve built up some absolutely marvelous opportunities. I mean, what are the options for a 93-year-old guy, them kicking everyone off the USS Arizona just to have me play my harmonica?’’
His performance at the Pearl Harbor Invitational basketball game has been viewed nearly 200,000 times on YouTube. What’s he expecting the NHL game to be like at the 20,000-seat BB&T Center?

“I don’t have the foggiest idea,’’ said DuPre, who grew up skating on the St. Lawrence River in Ogdensburg, St. Lawrence County. “I don’t know if it’ll beat Pearl Harbor, but it’ll be in a big place with a lot of people.’’
Such events have become old hat for the Rochester Institute of Technology alumnus and Bausch + Lomb retiree.
Last May, he was invited to the 50th anniversary of Charlie Company in Las Vegas where he played taps as names of the deceased who served in the Vietnam War infantry unit were read.
He’s a regular at airport receptions welcoming home veterans on Honor Flight trips to Washington, D.C.

“One thing I try to do is tell people that they should be there when that plane comes back from Washington,’’ DuPre said. “Some of those guys coming back, the Vietnam guys, they had no reception so it’s a chance for everyone to make up. These hardened guys come off the plane and they have no idea seeing that cheering crowd.’’

DuPre’s five children (he has five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren) are proud of his willingness to share his talents with the world in such a profound fashion. They’re not sure how he does it.
“My mom was sick for a very long time and he did nothing but take care of her,’’ daughter Mary Ann said. “I think this is kind of her way of thanking him for everything.’’
Mike DuPre marvels at his dad’s stamina.

“He was mom’s primary caregiver and after some mourning, opportunities started to happen with Honor Flight, the Greatest Generations Foundation,’’ he said. “It’s just taken off. I’ve said, ‘Dad, you get these invitations, if you want to stop sometime, just let me know,’ and he says, ‘As long as I’m standing and I’m still playing, just keep ‘em coming.’ ’’

One especially memorable trip (all are arranged and chaperoned by foundation organizers) was to the Eagles Nest, Adolph Hitler’s Third Reich era mountaintop meeting house at Berchtesgaden, Germany that is now a major tourist attraction. An elevator ride completes the journey to the top.

“We got on and the doors closed and people from all over the world are in there, 24 of us,’’ DuPre said. “We got to the top, the doors open and they come out singing with me playing God Bless America. That really went over well.’’
Pretty lofty stuff for a guy who doesn’t read music and learns by ear.
“I think when I was born God put a computer in here,’’ he said, tapping his forehead. “I listen and I play it.’’

DuPre’s dad was a traveling tobacco salesman and the family moved often. He first picked up the mouth organ at age 5 and while attending school near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Peter joined the harmonica band.
“My dad scared up 50 cents to buy me my first harmonica,’’ he said noting that during the Great Depression, “that was a lot of money.’’

Today he owns several dozen harmonicas, his favorite a German-made curved Hohner with the lettering worn smooth. The instrument fits so perfectly into his warm hands bearing the lines of a life fully lived, it's as if a puzzle piece has slid into place.
DuPre purchased it 50 years ago for $18.50. Last year, the iconic Hohner company presented Peter with two harmonicas valued at $400 each.

“I have quite a collection,’’ said DuPre, who wore a black World War II veteran's ball cap adorned with service pins. “Families come to me and say, ‘I found this in a drawer after Grandpa died’ and they’ve given me many harmonicas over the years. But this is my favorite. The sound, the volume, the key, it has a sound of its own.’’
As does DuPre whose talents can cause strangers to stop, listen, reflect, dance or sing when they hear a patriotic tune or a song from their youth.

During the war, DuPre’s harmonica playing soothed many souls recovering from battlefield wounds in the London hospital he was stationed in. His commanding officer always encouraged him to play something on long training marches to make the time pass easier.
“I played a lot during the war,’’ DuPre said. “I had to be in good shape physically to march 26 miles and play at the same time.’’
He’s still marching. Still doing what his calling card says, providing “music for the soul, from the heart.’’ Only now the world is his campfire.
LROTH@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: About 500 people on 10 buses left the Rochester area late Thursday to head down to Washington, D.C., for the March for Life Friday.
Led by Bishop Salvatore Matano, Catholics from throughout the 12-county Diocese of Rochester will meet up with thousands more for the 44th annual demonstration to end legalized abortion.
The march follows the Jan. 22 anniversary of the U.S. Supreme Court's Roe v. Wade decision in 1973 that legalized abortion.

Four of the buses were comprised mainly of students from Our Lady of Mercy and McQuaid Jesuit high schools. The Rev. William Coffas led a bus of 55 people from Our Mother of Sorrows Church in Greece, marking the first time the west-side congregation had sent a bus of parishioners to the event.

"We will pray for a greater respect of all human life, from the moment of conception until natural death," said Coffas, who led a prayer service before the bus departed from Greece. "We will pray that all human life will be celebrated as a gift from God.

Those headed to the march will attend a 10 a.m. mass Friday at the Basilica of the Immaculate Conception in Washington, which will be followed by a rally at the National Mall and the march to the Supreme Court building.

"The March for Life in Washington, D.C., began as a small demonstration and rapidly grew to be the largest pro-life event in the world," the event's website reads. It continues, "The mission of the March for Life is to provide all Americans with a place to testify to the beauty of life and the dignity of each human person."
Suzanne Stack, life issues coordinator for the Diocese of Rochester, was most excited about the number of students and young people headed to the march.

"We know they are the pro-life generation," Stack said. "We recognize the need to say, 'Hey, every human life matters, no matter how small.' We believe that unborn children, plus the mothers, deserve better than abortion. We want to say that every single life matters."
Coffas said they plan to arrive in Washington around 6 a.m., eat breakfast, and then head to Mass. After the march, they will board the bus and are expected to head back to Rochester around 4 p.m.
Buses also departed from Church of the Holy Spirit in Penfield, Holy Apostles Church in Rochester, and from spots in Ithaca and Horseheads.

Cardinal Timothy Dolan, archbishop of New York, and top presidential adviser Kellyanne Conway are scheduled to speak at the rally. Vice President Mike Pence announced Thursday on Twitter that he will also address the march. He become's the highest-ranking government official to speak in person at an annual anti-abortion march in Washington.
WCLEVELAND@Gannett.com
