articleBody.value: With the Fisk Jubilee Singers performing "Swing Low, Sweet Chariot," Rochester Institute of Technology held its 35th annual Expressions of King Legacy Thursday.

Keynote speaker Fredricka Whitfield, who is the CNN daytime weekend anchor, along with the other featured speaker, U.S. Circuit Judge Robert L. Wilkins, offered words of inspiration and evoked the Martin Luther King Jr. legacy.

The Jubilee Singers are vocal artists and students at Fisk University in Nashville, Tennessee. The group, which sings worldwide, has played a key role in preserving the musical tradition of African-American spirituals. The Jubilee Singers also performed Thursday evening as part of a program at the Third Presbyterian Church in Rochester.
Whitfield urged the crowd of about 500, who gathered at the Gordon Field House and Activities Center on the RIT campus, to set high goals and persist in pursuing them.
"Dream big — and often," she said.

Whitfield, 51, told how she was determined to become a journalist and started down that career path  as a student at Howard University in Washington, D.C. Her introduction to journalism was "ripping copy," pulling wire service stories off a teletype machine.
From then on, Whitfield told how she took advantage of every opportunity.
"I just wanted to seize the moment," she said.

Her first job out of college was as a reporter and morning TV anchor in Charleston, South Carolina. As her career progressed, she worked as a correspondent for NBC News and NBC Nightly News, The Today Show and Dateline NBC, before joining CNN in 2002.
In addition to her news anchor position, Whitfield works as a correspondent for CNN, reporting on breaking stories. She is based in Atlanta.

Whitfield received Ebony's award for Outstanding Women in Marketing and Communications in 2005 and is also a recipient of the George Peabody award for her coverage of Hurricane Katrina, as well as an Emmy award for outstanding live coverage of breaking news.
As a journalist, Whitfield also told of the need to adjust to changing technology, from the days of lugging heavy equipment to the hand-held smartphones of today.
She drew inspiration from her father, Mal Whitfield, a middle-distance runner who won five Olympic medals — including three gold medals — in the 1948 and 1952 Olympics.
During World War II, he was a member of the Tuskegee Airmen and in 1955 became the State Department's Sports Goodwill Ambassador.
Her mother, Nola, became the first African-American model for mainstream products. "She, too, was a trailblazer," Whitfield noted.
And Whitfield told the RIT audience, "The most valuable lesson is how important it is to have an open mind, to be determined, to be driven."
Wilkins is the author of the new book, Long Road to Hard Truth: The 100-year Mission to Create the National Museum of African American History and Culture.

The book tells how an effort to create a monument for African-American soldiers in 1916 eventually led to the opening last September of this museum on the National Mall. Wilkins was part of the effort to create it.
"It is truly a spectacular institution," said Wilkins. "What you may not understand is that this museum is a demonstration of the King legacy."
He told of the obstacles and resistance to building such a museum that were overcome.
"African-Americans do deserve to have their contributions to America recognized," Wilkins said.
JGOODMAN@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: ALBANY - New York is looking to legalize ride-hailing services outside New York City, but there would be surcharges placed on riders and taxes lodged against the companies.

In his budget plan last week, Gov. Andrew Cuomo proposed a 5.5 percent "state assessment" fee on every trip given by companies like Uber and Lyft across New York. The majority would go to the state's general fund to pay for services and program.
There would also be a 2 percent surcharge to cover worker compensation costs for drivers.

Cuomo has vowed to get a deal with the state Legislature to allow for the companies to operate outside New York City. Currently, each community has its own taxi laws, making it impossible for Uber and Lyft to operate outside New York City, which has its own livery regulations and policies.

"It is unfair, and you can’t justify allowing it in New York City but not allowing it in upstate New York," Cuomo said Tuesday in Rochester. "We made it a priority in the budget because it’s only right that we pass it in upstate New York, and we want to do it this year."
►Cuomo touts Uber, criminal justice plans
►Cuomo to unveil Uber plan for upstate
►Uber, taxis at odds in Albany
The state's coffers would also benefit from an agreement.
The Democratic governor's budget projects $16 million in revenue this year from ride sharing, and $32 million in the subsequent years — based on estimates of 15,000 drivers.
About 27 percent of the assessment fee would go to help fund local transit services, the bill said. So there would be a piece for local programs.
Uber said it appreciates Cuomo's efforts, even as lawmakers question his proposal.
“Thank you, Governor Cuomo for listening to the voices of New Yorkers who are demanding affordable, reliable transportation options like Uber," the company said in a statement.
"It’s time for the Empire State to join New York City and the 47 other states in allowing ride-sharing services to operate.”

His bill would allow the state Department of Motor Vehicles to audit the companies, require them to do a series of background checks on drivers and have at least $1 million of insurance for every ride.
The 2 percent surcharge to cover worker compensation costs would be revisited by a board appointed by Cuomo, legislative leaders and industry officials, which would then set a permanent rate.
Assembly Insurance Committee chairman Kevin Cahill, D-Kingston, said he has concerns about Cuomo's bill, including stripping local governments of any control over the ride-sharing companies.
"We have concerns about the liability limits that might not reflect the risk in the governor’s bill," Cahill said Thursday.
"And certainly we have great concerns about levying a statewide tax that gets distributed according to a formula that he determined, as opposed to something that might better suit each locality."
State lawmakers were unable to reach an agreement to legalize the ride services before the 2016 legislative session ended last June.
Then, Cuomo tried to strike a deal on ride-hailing as part of a potential special session last month. But the session never materialized.
Now Cuomo is trying to get a deal as part of the state budget for the fiscal year that starts April 1.

content.author: Joseph Spector, Albany Bureau Chief
content.headline: Want Uber? The state would tax you

articleBody.value: “Culture” is more than just a workplace buzzword at Innovative Solutions.

The Brighton-based IT company emphasizes the concept, to the point of creating a position of “director of culture.” Channeling his inner Willy Wonka, Innovative CEO Justin Copie shared the company’s “Golden Ticket,” which lists “golden rules” like “biography is not destiny.”
So, what’s it all mean?

“It’s what makes people feel fulfilled and excited to come to work,” Copie said. “Also, it’s the type of experience we deliver to clients ... the feeling that they get from working with us. We’ve really, really focused over the past three years on our culture.”

That’s especially important in the oft-maligned field of IT, or information technology, Copie said. We’ve all seen the stereotypical IT technician, the computer geek who’s amazing with RAM and ROM but not so much with, well, much else. (Ever see the show The Middle and one of its characters, Kenny? Yeah, like him.)
READ MORE: Find a new Small Business Spotlight every week.
Innovative Solutions is looking for computer-savvy employees, of course, but also those who have a wide variety of interests. Those who, you know, have a life offline.

“Our people are people first,” Copie said. “We hire based on personality and ‘EQ,’ or ‘emotional quotient.’ If we hire people with a high EQ, we have better interaction with our clients. It’s people first, and then technology.”
Apologies for the stereotypes, but Copie said the Kenny-type figure is “still very much prevalent” in the IT world — just not at Innovative Solutions.

“I hear so many tough stories (about techs) who just understand technology but don’t understand people,” he said. “If you understand, you have real conversations with people and let them make their own decisions.”

Innovative Solutions started in 1989 as a software development company that grew to include network capabilities in 2000. The firm stayed fairly small until the mid-1990s, when Microsoft Windows Business debuted and upped the demand for technical support.

Founder Paul McMahon eventually sold Innovative Solutions to Bob Titus, who sold the company a year or so ago to Copie. Titus remains as chairman; Bob Dunning, who has been with Innovative since its inception as a partner, is listed as principal consultant.

Innovative Solutions was named to the Democrat and Chronicle’s most recent “Top Workplaces” list. Copie said the company’s culture — there’s that word again — factors heavily in the recognition. Talented IT technicians are in extremely high demand, he said, particularly those with good “people” skills.

“Among our staff ... each one gets recruited 10 times per year,” Copie said. “That is so competitive. If we don’t keep them fulfilled, they’ll get scooped up tomorrow. That’s why we work so hard to keep people so happy, so fulfilled.”

With perks and benefits, Innovative Solutions is, well, innovative. Included are catered lunch daily, unlimited PTO (personal time off), 14 paid holidays (“two are completely our own”), and, starting this year, a $1,000 stipend per employee when he or she goes on vacation. The company even has a full-time “concierge” to coordinate employees’ vacations.
“We want our staff to have a good life-work balance,” Copie said. That means knowing your computer stuff, of course, but also knowing there’s more to life than just the online world.
Alan Morrell is a Rochester-based freelance writer.
Innovative Solutions
Founded: 1989.
Location: 3495 Winton Place, Building C, Brighton.
Executives: Justin Copie, CEO; Bob Titus, chairman; Bob Dunning, principal consultant.
Employees: 75.
Website: www.innovativesol.com.

articleBody.value: It's time to make restaurant reservations for Valentine's Day, but let's face it, this is one holiday that can be tricky to navigate.

You need to find the Goldilocks of restaurants: one that's not too loud, not too casual and not too extravagant. Here are restaurant suggestions that are just right for the major stages in most romantic relationships.

Valentine's Day falls on a Tuesday this year, so the weekend before and after the actual holiday are both fair game for celebrating. Mark the actual day with a kiss, a card or some flowers and plan your night out on a day when you're not tired from the weekly grind.
Single, by circumstance or choice

First, let's acknowledge that single life has advantages. Singles tend to have more psychological growth and be more connected to parents, siblings, friends, neighbors and coworkers, according to Bella DePaulo, a social psychologist at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Still, being surrounded by romantic couples on Valentine's Day can bring on unwanted comparisons and pressure. To combat this, plan a fun night out with friends at a place that's a bit less conducive to canoodling.

You can make a night of it in the building that houses both AJ's Tap and Steakhouse and The Comedy Club, at 2235 Empire Blvd. in Webster. Kick off the evening with an early dinner at AJ's, which has a casual, western vibe. Head to The Comedy Club for some laughs. Finish out the evening by returning to AJ's to take in a local rock band; they play on weekends.

Playhouse Swillburger at 820 S. Clinton Ave. is also a great spot for a lighthearted night out. Grab a burger (they offer both meat and veggie versions), creative tots or a kale salad. Visit the craft cocktail bar and chat, or try your luck at the classic arcade games and pinball machines.
First date
Whether you are on a blind date or meeting someone from an online dating site, the best spot for a first date enables you to hedge your bets, while leaving room for possibilities.

Coffee shops are a classic spot. At the recently expanded Joe Bean Coffee Roasters at 1344 University Ave., you can grab a cup of coffee and enjoy it at the central bar or take it to a table. If things are going well, order a shared plate or entrée from its new food menu or move on to beer and wine. Or head next door to Mullers Cider House for hard cider and house-made kettle corn.

A place with a large, lively bar is another good option. Jojo Bistro and Wine Bar, at 60 N. Main St. in Pittsford, is one such spot. It's a large bar with lots of seats and a good selection of beers and wines by the glass. If you stay for dinner, options such as wood-fired pizzas won't break the bank.

Leaf Tea Bar, 650 South Ave., calls itself a sober pub, so it's a place to meet if you both are nondrinkers or have a shared interest in a healthy lifestyle. It is a serene environment and it's fascinating to watch owner Niraj Lama carefully prepare each cup of tea. If you would like to prolong the date, there are a great many options in walking distance in the South Wedge.
READ MORE: Recent restaurant reviews
In the friend zone
Whether you'd like to simply enjoy a night with a friend, or hope to move the relationship to the next level, these are places that are fun and interactive.

Explore food and drink at Flight Wine Bar, at 262 Exchange Blvd. in Corn Hill Landing, and Flight West, at 836 Long Pond Road in Greece. Flight Wine Bar focuses on flights of wine, cheeses, charcuterie and chocolates. Flight West adds whiskeys to the mix, and also offers cocktails and a more extensive menu.

Get a little adventurous with Ethiopian food. The dishes are served together on a tray, and everyone eats from the tray. Abyssinia Restaurant, in Mt. Hope Plaza at 1657 Mt. Hope Ave., is one of the nicer Ethiopian places in town. A bonus is that prices are reasonable; dinner for two is $22.95 and up. Plus, there are a lot of vegetarian and vegan items.

With Korean barbecue, you cook your own marinated proteins on a grill in the middle of the table. Plus, it's fun to taste all the complimentary sides, called banchan. My go-to spot for Korean barbecue is Seoul House Korean Restaurant, 2805 West Henrietta Road in Brighton.
Head over heels
The sparks are flying and you can't get enough of each other. Here are a few places made for romance.

The Marketplace Mall may not immediately come to mind, but the fondue restaurant chain The Melting Pot strikes a lot of romantic notes. The dining room is softly lit, with high-backed booths that create an intimate vibe. My suggestion is to start with one of the cheesy fondues, then take a breather from the richness with a salad. Skip the entrées, which are difficult to cook properly. Finish with the dark chocolate fondue, served with a variety of dippers.

There's a saying that dancing is a vertical expression of a horizontal desire. True? Find out for yourself at Tapas 177 Lounge. It often has live salsa bands for Latin dancing on Saturday nights. If you don't have any moves, drop in on free salsa lessons on Thursdays. Otherwise, just let the music move you — it's a dimly lit space, so who will see? The restaurant serves globally inspired small plates to share, plus some entrées, with lots of vegan, vegetarian and gluten-free choices. Tapas 177 is at 177 St Paul St. downtown.

If you'd like your romantic meals to align with your values, Lento, a fine dining fixture in the Village Gate Square, has been focusing on locally sourced fare for roughly a decade now. The inventive menu changes frequently, so there are new surprises at each visit. Notable for romance: The space is softly lit, the cocktails are creative and it is known for its oysters. Village Gate is 274 N. Goodman St.
Comfortable couple

When you've been together for a while, the need for the stereotypical candlelit ambience can be less of a priority, but it's still nice to enjoy a delicious meal in an intimate environment. Here are three intimate restaurants special enough for Valentine's Day.

The 24-seat Atlas Eats, at 2185 N. Clinton Ave. in Irondequoit finds inspiration from around the world. Its Edible Atlas menu is a price-fixed menu that explores a different cuisine every couple of weeks. The price for the five-course meal is a reasonable $39, plus wine. It is only served on Fridays and Saturdays and will not be open Valentine's Day.

The cuisine of Il Mare Mediterranean Kitchen has a narrower focus. It spans the huge Mediterranean Sea, offering a diverse menu from Greek to Sicilian to Spanish. The cozy restaurant is at 159 W. Main St. in Webster. Save room for the homemade desserts.

Questa Lasagna is a charming restaurant on a charming stretch of Main Street in Mount Morris. Its heavenly lasagnas, layered in individual oblong baking dishes, are made from homemade pasta. At 55 Main St., it is a short drive from the north entrance of the Letchworth State Park, so you could add an off-season visit to the stunning state park.
Exhausted new parents

When baby is a bundle of needs, it's hard to squeeze in time for dining between the frequent feedings, diaper changes and irregular sleeping. Make it easy on yourselves by ordering from one of the many places that deliver more than just pizza and Chinese food.

If you're near the city, the Park Avenue Paninoteca is known for their creative panini, but also offers arancini and gnocchi, as well as desserts such as tiramisu and Nutella cheesecake. Or make dinner of dessert with delivery from Sinful Sweets, at the corner of Park Avenue and Alexander Street.  Among its many creative cupcake flavors are lust and temptation, perfect for the romantic holiday.

Benucci's , a locally owned Italian restaurant with locations in Pittsford and Greece, makes classics such as lasagna Bolognese and chicken Parmesan. Or go a little fancier. Start with a fun trio of bruschetta, and follow it with lobster ravioli in a tomato cream sauce, topped with grilled shrimp. Benucci's also has many gluten-free options and a nice selection of desserts.
Need more ideas? Check out Grubhub.com.
Parents home with kids
If you decide to stay home with the kids, you can still pull off a romantic evening with the kiddos at home.

If family members are carnivores, head to McCann's Local Meats at 739 S Clinton Ave. in the South Wedge for some locally sourced meats. Ask the butchers to recommend a cut of meat and how to cook it, and perhaps grab some ground beef to make burgers for the kids. Round off your meal with their prepared meats and sides, including Korean fare.

If your taste runs more surf than turf (or if you'd like both), try Palmer Direct to You Market at the Genesee Valley Regional Market Authority, 900 W. Jefferson Road in Henrietta. Cook at home or let them complete the task for you. Some of the choices include handmade crab cakes, lobster bisque, seafood chowder and bouillabaisse.

Rochester's many, many red sauce Italian joints — too many to list — are also great options for takeout, and are kid-friendly to boot. The prices are generally reasonable and they will usually bundle up the whole meal, from pasta to rolls to salad. Order cannolis for dessert.
Parents dining with kids

Many of today's parents are comfortable taking their children to just about any restaurant, and Valentine's Day will be no different. Hibachi is a great alternative because it offers built-in entertainment, while parents get a chance to enjoy grown-up fare. Sogo Japanese Steakhouse is a tried-and-true option; in addition to hibachi, it offers sushi and fusion dishes. It has two locations, at 980 Ridge Road in Webster and in the Mall at Greece Ridge in Greece. Another dependable option is Umi Japanese Steakhouse in Victor's Cobblestone Court.
Parents in need of a getaway
What a treat to have an overnight sitter when you're busy parents. As luck would have it, several of the area's nicer hotels offer excellent restaurants.

The Strathallan Rochester, now a DoubleTree by Hilton Hotel, has the contemporary, high-end Char Steak and Lounge, which does a beautiful job with steaks and other gastronomic delights. On its ninth floor is Hattie's, a sophisticated lounge that offers imaginative cocktails, sushi and panoramic views of the city.
The Del Monte Lodge, at 41 N. Main St. in Pittsford, offers the elegant Erie Grill, which puts a modern American spin on familiar favorites. It also is known for its creative cocktails.

If you'd like to get out of town, drive an hour or so to the Aurora Inn on Cayuga Lake. The country inn with white-columned balconies offers farm-to-table dining at the lakefront Aurora Inn Dining Room. If you have an ample budget, look into their food and wine packages. It is at 391 Main St. in Aurora, Cayuga County.
Empty nesters

When you are raising kids, it can feel like your time is not your own, with school events, sporting events and more. Now that the kids are out of the house, why not make a night of it by visiting a couple of spots?

Ristorante Lucano is a perennial favorite for classic Italian fare, with a huge list of specials each night. The restaurant at 1815 East Ave. is divided into three small dining rooms that are great for quiet conversation. If you'd prefer continental cuisine, head to the Park Avenue Pub and Restaurant, 650 Park Ave., for pasta, seafood and steak. Start or finish the evening at the nearby Chocolate and Vines, a cozy Victorian house at 757 University Ave. that specializes in pairing wines and craft beers with chocolates, cheeses and desserts.

Proietti's , a classy Italian restaurant at 980 Ridge Road in Webster, is a longtime favorite. Don't let its strip mall location deter you; it has a pleasant intimate feel. Finish with a night cap at the tucked-away Vino Bar (also called Vino Lounge), a cozy full-service bar, hidden behind Mozzaroni's in the village of Webster at 27 W. Main St. There's often live music on the weekends, starting at 7 or 8 p.m. and going to 11 p.m.

Two restaurants across the parking lot from each other in Pittsford's Northfield Common at 50 State St. offer several options for progressive dining. The charming Label 7 serves California-inspired cuisine, as well as craft cocktails and California wines. Nestled in the basement of a building, the quaint Olives Greek Taverna serves both classic and Americanized Greek fare. A cocktail and small plates at Label 7, followed by baklava at Olives? That would work. Greek fare at Olives followed by doughnut bread pudding at Label 7? Yeah, that would work, too.
TRACYS@Gannett.com

relatedLinks.linkText: WATCH: Warren talks about Sanctuary Cities

articleBody.value: Mayor Lovely Warren offered measured push back this week against President Donald Trump's executive order threatening to yank federal funding from cities with policies that protect undocumented immigrants.

Trump signed executive orders Wednesday promising to punish so-called sanctuary cities, while pledging to step up deportation efforts, expand immigration jails and push forward with construction of a wall at the Mexican border.

“Our intention is to protect our citizens while abiding by federal law," Warren said in a prepared statement. "In the days ahead the city will work with the attorney general and the federal government to ensure that, while we remain in full compliance with federal law, city resources won’t be used unnecessarily to perform tasks meant solely for immigration enforcement."

Rochester will receive at least $5.6 million in federal funding this fiscal year — no small amount, but just 1 percent of the city budget. It is not clear how much of that could be at risk, as what action Trump actually can or will take remains a question.

"We are all trying to figure out what can be done by executive order," said Kent Gardner, principal and chief economist with the Center for Governmental Research. "Both George Bush and Barack Obama pushed the envelope on that."

"Sanctuary city" is not a legal term, but rather is generally applied to those communities that — for reasons of social activism, police-community relations, budget or otherwise — choose to protect or not pursue details about residents' immigration or citizenship status. It is not a matter of sheltering or concealing undocumented immigrants, they argue, but not voluntarily or actively assisting with immigration enforcement.

Census records show that Rochester's foreign-born population grew by 18.5 percent between 2009 and 2015, topping 19,000. The increase is represented almost entirely by non-citizens, but how many were undocumented is not known.
►Mayor Warren to update Rochester's sanctuary city resolution
►Petition at UR seeks status as sanctuary campus
►How Trump can defund 'sanctuary cities' protecting undocumented immigrants
►New York City mayor says president can't defund sanctuary cities 'across the board'

Much of the city's federal allotment is in community development block grant funding, used to assist with affordable housing, anti-poverty programs and infrastructure. Other funding goes to support pregnancy prevention, job training, child literacy and summer lunch programs, domestic abuse victims, homeland security and to combat gun crime.

Trump's executive order seems to direct the focus to Department of Justice and Homeland Security funding. Community policing and training could be affected, said Rick Su, professor at the University at Buffalo School of Law but the administration presumably would stop short of impacting anti-terrorism, immigration and broader law enforcement capabilities.

"I think that is going to be a relatively small amount," Su said. "To exert the most amount of pressure, they would be cutting into areas that are politically sensitive and undermining (their own) priorities."

Warren is a lawyer, which could partly explain the measured response. Others, including Boston Mayor Marty Walsh, blasted Trump. Walsh called the president's action a “destructive and un-American threat.”

Syracuse Mayor Stephanie Miner issued statement similar to Warren's, saying: "The resources of the city of Syracuse, including the Syracuse Police Department, are not being used to enforce federal anti-immigrant policies nor are they empowered to do so. We do not intend to change this practice and will scrutinize any proposed changes at the federal level thoroughly.”

State Attorney General Eric Schneiderman, a Democrat, said Trump "lacks the constitutional authority to cut off funding to states and cities simply because they have lawfully acted to protect immigrant families." Schneiderman last week put out a list of "sanctuary" policies and actions, which Warren had said the city would seek to adopt. Many, however, dealt with handling those taken into custody, and the Monroe County Sheriff's Office operates the jail. Through a spokesman, the sheriff's office indicated it fully cooperates with federal immigration authorities.

How the Trump administration appears to define uncooperative is quite limited — relying on a section of the U.S. code that prohibits any restriction on state or local officials from communicating with federal officials about immigration status. But the law does not require use of local resources to assist, Su said, adding that sanctuary cities also get around this by not allowing local officials to inquire about immigration status, thus leaving them with no information to share.

Rochester police have no policy either directing or prohibiting an officer from asking about an individual's residency or citizenship status. But when someone is arrested, officers complete a Prisoner Data Report that seeks answers on both issues. A person can refuse. That report is then provided to the sheriff's office, which then might contact federal officials while seeking to verify the identity of those in custody, officials said. The sheriff's office also accepts funding to join with other agencies in maritime border protection and commercial vehicle enforcement details.

Ultimately, experts said, efforts to de-fund sanctuary cities could be met with constitutional challenges under the 10th amendment. The federal government is not allowed to "commandeer" state and local government by forcing compliance with a federal mandate. This came into play under Obamacare's Medicaid expansion — where states could be enticed with more money, but not punished with reduced funding.

"The guiding force are those (past) court rulings that say local governments don’t need to play the role of the federal government," said city of Rochester spokesman James Smith, admittedly uncertain about what lies ahead.

"Rochester has had a longstanding commitment and a belief that we need to protect the rights of all of our residents," he said, adding: "We will not engage in willfully violating federal or state laws. As we move forward our intent is to comply with laws at the federal or state level that affect us."
BDSHARP@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: — Our editors review and recommend products to help you buy the stuff you need. If you make a purchase by clicking one of our links, we may earn a small share of the revenue. Our picks and opinions are independent from any business incentives.

When I was a kid, my mother co-founded a nut butter company. She and her childhood best friend pioneered a business that specialized in gourmet spreads: Almond, cashew, peanut, honey, and my favorite, cinnamon, which tasted like your grandmother’s best coffee cake when layered on warm toast. Our house became the (richly scented) hub from which they churned out jars to send to retailers and cases to cart to gourmet food shows.

In fact, it was at the New York Fancy Food Show that crowds flocked to their tiny booth, creating a buzz large enough to attract a well-known celebrity chef. She loved the product, but she detected a trace of rancidity in the spreads and asked my mom and her friend if they roasted the nuts in-house. They did not, but they had just learned an important lesson: The only way to guarantee fresh nut butter is to roast your own nuts.

Why? Generally speaking, roasted nuts have a shorter shelf life than their fresh counterparts. The reason why is scientific and complex, but the simple version is that roasting breaks down the oil within the nut, exposing it to more oxygen, and heightening the risk for rancidity. And if you’re ordering roasted nuts from a third party, you can’t really know how long they’ve been sitting around before they make it to your door.

You may be wondering, why bother roasting the nuts at all? Well, I’m glad you asked. Think of the flavor difference between bread and toast. Roasted nuts are integral to a richer, fuller tasting butter, and if you blend while the nuts are still warm, a smoother product results.

My mother’s business couldn’t afford the exorbitant industrial roaster and eventually went under for it, which is a shame because that stuff was objectively delicious. But if you’re interested in grinding your own nut butter, there are some smaller, budget-friendly roasters you can snag for the freshest and best-tasting homemade spreads. I’m sure even a Food Network star would agree.
Back to Basics Nut Roaster — $51.84 on Amazon

Reviewers love this product for its nonstick aluminum pan and and high-quality, "burly construction." At four stars with more than 50 reviews, this is one of Amazon's top-selling nut roasters and comes at an extremely fair price. Another bonus: This model's nonstick finish makes glazing nuts a breeze, so that if you choose, you can do so in under 10 minutes to quickly whip up a sweet, warm mix.
West Bend Kettle Krazy Popcorn Popper and Nut Roaster — $40.49 on Amazon

Fun fact: Many people use the same product to pop popcorn, roast coffee beans, and roast nuts. This particular model is billed as a two-in-one popper and roaster that can roast up to three cups of nuts at a time. The motorized stir rod keeps nuts in constant motion to ensure even roasting. Though it has a mix of reviews on Amazon, the manufacturer swears this model is the best for roasting due to its thick stirrers and metal heat base.
Whirley-Pop Stovetop Popcorn Popper — $29.49 on Amazon

I guess it's no secret that I apparently have a thing for Whirley-Pop's classic stovetop popper. But its patented design includes a well-loved stirring mechanism and an aluminum pan that heats evenly to prevent scorching, which makes the Whirley-Pop perfect for nut roasting. The brand website even has a collection of roasted nut recipes, including this cinnamon glazed recipe that would make an excellent base for a butter—and not far off from one of my mother's original recipes, either.

content.author: Jessica Rose Teich, USA TODAY

articleBody.value: Low interest rates and consumer confidence helped push homes sales in the Greater Rochester region up 7.9 percent  in 2016 compared to the previous year.
The Greater Rochester Association of Realtors released its year-end sales Thursday showing the improvement in real estate trends when it comes to sales of existing single-family homes.

Home prices remained relatively unchanged across the region. Monroe county saw a slight increase in median sales price to
$133,000, up from $132,000 the previous year, according to Greater Rochester Association of Realtors.

"Prices held steady across the entire region, but did not make the gains one might expect given the conditions of low inventory, low interest rates, multiple offers, and higher demand,” said Linda Wilson, board president of Greater Rochester Association of Realtors. “This trend has to do with the stability of our regional market. We usually fall in the middle of the road as compared to other areas in the nation, escaping the high-highs and low-lows of the curve.”

The number of new listings for the year fell 6.3 percent. Areas that showed strong growth include the city of Rochester, with a 19.5 percent increase in sales as compared to 2015, East Rochester with a 40.5 percent gain and Gates a 31.1 percent increase.

Sales of new build homes were strong as well, said Rick Herman, CEO of Rochester Home Builders' Association. New home construction permits for 2016 in Monroe County saw a slight decrease, neighboring counties of Wayne and Ontario continue to grow.

The growth area is in Ontario County, with 453 new single family permits in 2016, compared to 329 in 2015.
Total building permits for Monroe, Ontario and Wayne Counties were up slightly to 1,308 single family homes and 419 multi-family homes. Ontario County had an increase of 124 building permits and Wayne County had an increase of 40.
Patio homes and attached homes are popular in new home construction, Herman said.
"Residential housing has changed over the last 10 years. We are seeing more attached single-family residences," Herman said.
MCHAO@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: A wooden-looking fashion figure in a bright red, knee-length cocktail dress stands stock still on a box in front of Macy’s. An electric extension cord leading out from the box adds to the illusion. The figure suddenly springs to life and breaks into a robotic dance. Shoppers stare up at her, some laughing, others with their mouths open. Is she real?

Tall, thin and blue-eyed with cropped blonde hair, Greece native Carrie Schreiner has been causing astonished double takes from passersby long before the Mannequin Challenge became the hottest fad on social media.

A  full-time paralegal at Leclair Korona Vahey Cole by day, she moonlights as a robotic mannequin model at venues ranging from Rochester and Buffalo area malls, to perfume counters and bridal shops, to the Fringe Festival, Fashion Week of Rochester, and local charity benefits. She has a regular gig at Macy’s, appearing at their stores at least 10 times a year. Here's how she does it:
Carrie's six mannequin-modeling tips
Carrie Schreiner’s technique is based in pantomime or “mime,” using movement and facial expressions to convey meaning.  She shares some of her techniques.

1. Learn not to Blink:  The most difficult part is not allowing yourself to blink. “It’s something that comes with doing it a long time and knowing how to dismiss the urge to blink and also depends on the air quality.” Insufficient ventilation can cause your eyes to tear.

2. Stay in Shape:  Upper body strength training is important. “I feel like a runner who gets in the groove. I enjoy the physical exertion of it.” To keep her body conditioned, she works out with 10 pound weights and does leg exercises.

3. Achieve the right mindset: To remain in character she pretends she is made of plastic or is a China doll. “It’s all about your mind controlling your body and it helps me be still. It’s not just movements. It’s movements in comparison to stillness.”  The intense concentration also helps her to ignore hecklers or those trying to make her laugh.

4. Professional makeup:  “I always wear matte lipstick (never glossy) and always red. I use clear nail polish because mannequins don’t have nails.” She makes her legs look plastic by wearing stockings with a sheer sheen that reflects the light.
5. Watch the time: With gigs lasting 1 ½ to 3 hours, Schreiner always wears a watch. “People in the store sometimes forget about you.”
6. When dealing with children:  Bow to them, smile and wave to make them more comfortable.
How she started
How does one get into such an odd field?
It didn’t hurt that Schreiner’s mother was a professional model and that her dad, an iron worker, was a drummer on the side. “I have his love of music and rhythm.”

But Schreiner’s mannequin modeling career actually arrived like a bolt out of the blue when Shawn Duffy, a Cardinal Mooney High School classmate, asked her to join him in a school talent show. He was a fan of popular TV mime team Shields and Yarnell, who were famous for doing a robotic bit called “The Clinkers.”

“Shawn wrote a skit, taught me some moves he invented, and we did the show. We were a husband and wife, him sitting at the kitchen table wearing a fake moustache, sweater and pipe, and me in a dress.”

Things took off in a big way from there. Duffy was friends with the manager of AJ’s Tux Shop in Greece Town Mall, and the couple began modelling in the store in tuxedos. The appearance caught the eye of Bridal Hall’s owner, who hired the duo to perform in their window and at their annual bridal shows. Two engaged couples were captivated and hired them to entertain at their weddings.

Duffy moved out of state, and Schreiner began to perform solo with the help of Barbara Dell, founder and owner of the Azetah Model and Talent Management Company who ran all of the Wilmorite mall fashion shows and promotional events. (Dell continues to run the agency, but has moved to Fort Myers, Florida, where she is also CEO for Dress for Success, SW Florida.)

Speaking from Fort Myers, Dell chuckles as she recalls her shocked reaction at Schreiner’s modeling audition in 1998. “I said, ‘Oh, my gosh!’ And then we lived happily ever after. Carrie is a full blooming force in terms of the modeling world. What’s fun is that she stands in a mannequin pose and breaks out, and people are shocked. She’s added something unique to the agency nobody else could.”

Over the years, Schreiner became Dell’s part-time assistant and taught other Azetah agency models how to take “freeze” poses. They can hold a pose for 15 or 20 minutes, says Dell, but none can imitate the robotic dance moves or hold a candle to Schreiner’s passion, concentration and unique talent.

At mall events, kids often plop themselves in front of Schreiner and older folks pull up chairs to enjoy the show. And that, Schreiner says, “is really the best thing for me about doing it – giving people a few minutes of enjoyment and making people happy.”

“I’m 55 and there’s no problem doing it right now,” says Schreiner. “I’ve had a very good run.”  But at some point, she may have to quit. Before that happens, she says, “I’d like to appear at a fashion show in New York because it’s the fashion capital. That would be the culmination, the pinnacle, of almost 40 years of doing this.”
You can see Schreiner in action on YouTube https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_QNuGPS0jOJ6Fs1pTwjNrA visit her FaceBook page at Carrie Schreiner Mannequin Model.
More

Search Facebook at Carrie Schreiner Mannequin Model. Schreiner will be at Legends 102.7 “All You Need Is Love Valentines Party”  from 5 to 11 p.m. on Saturday, Feb. 11, at the Italian American Community Center, 150 Frank Dimino Way. Tickets include a cocktail hour, buffet, live music and dance. Event cost is $95 a couple or $55 per individual. For more information, call (585) 264-1027. She will also model at the entrance to Macy’s Eastview Mall from 1 to 4 p.m. Saturday, F

content.shortHeadline: Is she real? Greece woman is a mannequin model
content.about: A wooden-looking fashion figure in a bright red, knee-length cocktail dress stands stock still on a box in front of Macy’s. An electric extension cord leading out from the box adds to the illusion. The figure suddenly springs to life and breaks into a robotic dance. Shoppers stare up at her, some laughing, others with their mouths open. Is she real?Tall, thin and blue-eyed with cropped blonde hair, Greece native Carrie Schreiner has been causing astonished double takes from passersby long before the Mannequin Challenge became the hottest fad on social media.A full-time paralegal at Leclair Korona Vahey Cole by day, she moonlights as a robotic mannequin model at venues ranging from Rochester and Buffalo area malls, to perfume counters and bridal shops, to the Fringe Festival, Fashion Week of Rochester, and local charity benefits. She has a regular gig at Macy’s, appearing at their stores at least 10 times a year. Here's how she does it:

articleBody.value: After reporting that Rochester City Court Judge Leticia Astacio couldn't recall her alleged drunken run-in with a security guard in a Marketplace Mall bar bathroom, I heard from several readers asking why the people couldn't just recall her.
"Why don't the citizens have the power to recall her election to this position?" one asked.
The simple answer is there's no mechanism in state law for voters to recall elected officials, let alone judges. That's not for a lack of trying.

For years, state legislators on both sides of the aisle have repeatedly introduced legislation in Albany that would give the public the power to petition for recall elections. Those bills never get out of committee.
Assembly Minority Leader Brian Kolb, a Republican from Canandaigua who sponsored a recall measure, explained why.
"I think it's been a mindset that the status quo doesn't want there to be an opportunity to change the status quo," said Kolb, who plans to reintroduce his bill this year.

Recalling a sitting judge is almost unheard of. Nineteen states and the District of Columbia permit the recall of state officials, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. But only eight of them allow for judges to be recalled.
That's because the prevailing view is that the judiciary should be insulated from political pressure and popular opinion.

To protect judges from public whimsy, most states that allow judicial recall stipulate that recalls can only happen for cause, according to the Marshall Project, a nonprofit new organization that covers the judicial system.
Those causes include acts of malfeasance, such as committing a crime while in office, or "nonfeasance," meaning they fail to perform their job as required by law.
Sound arguments could be made that Astacio's antics check both those boxes.

If the outcry on social media is any guide, people are fed up with Astacio. They're fed up not only because she’s proven herself a defiant disgrace to the judiciary, but also because they're tired of paying her to do nothing.
Her supervisors haven’t let her preside in court since she was charged with drunken driving a year ago, and in the fall they barred her from non-public areas of the courthouse.
They did those things because it was their only way to protect the integrity of the courts. They can't fire Astacio.
Only the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, the body tasked with disciplining judges, can get rid of her. Whether the commission will do so is anyone's guess.
A drunken driving conviction is typically not enough for the commission to remove a judge.

But Astacio has violated the condition of her sentence, and is now accused of doing so again by allegedly participating in a drinking party and allegedly pulling rank on a security guard in a bar bathroom.
She doesn't belong back on the bench.
Still, the commission often takes a year, sometimes two and three years, to arrive at a decision. Then, the decision can be appealed to the state's highest court.
Even if the commission elected to remove Astacio, taxpayers wouldn't be relieved of her until at least 2018, possibly 2019, if she chose to fight the decision.
In a recall process, like the one that would be permissible under Kolb's legislation, the people could oust Astacio in six to nine months.

Kolb's bill would require a recall petition for a judge be signed by registered voters equal in number to at least 20 percent of the last vote total for the office. An election could be held within 180 days of the signatures being certified.

Astacio was elected in 2014 with 22,780 votes, meaning a recall petition would need 4,556 signatures of registered city voters to prompt a vote. The outcry against her suggests that number is attainable.
Among the arguments against recall elections is that they're expensive, which they are.
But recall that Astacio was elected to a 10-year term at a salary of $173,700. Her getting paid to do nothing is expensive, too.
David Andreatta is a Democrat and Chronicle columnist. He can be reached at dandreatta@gannett.com.

articleBody.value: An alternative option was introduced Thursday for the stalled hotel project on the shores of Canandaigua Lake.

But area residents need not get their hopes up of seeing any immediate action, Canandaigua City Manager Ted Andrzejewski said Friday morning. The current hotel project launched with fanfare in 2015 to build the Canandaigua Finger Lakes Resort on the former site of the Streamboat Landing restaurant.

At a Thursday evening planned unit development committee meeting, Canandaigua City Council members heard the alternative plan as a project consultant outlined an option to include 80 to 100 apartments on the parcel, as well as a restaurant, spa and pool, Andrzejewski said,

"We're open to ideas and suggestions" for the parcel, which is owned by Canandaigua businessman David Genecco, he said. "This is nice and a good idea, but the design that's approved is for a hotel and is what stands."

For anything else to be built on site would require project developers to submit new plans that would also require rezoning. The lakeside property is currently zoned for commercial use, specifically for the unfinished hotel project that leaves a steel skeleton next to Kershaw Park.
The city approved several iterations of Genecco's project in 2010 and 2013, both of which included plans for a hotel and condominiums. Workers broke ground in 2014.
The project mysteriously stalled in July 2016 when major developers Robert Morgan of Morgan Management and David Christa of Christa Construction abruptly yanked their support.
"The consultant came in (Thursday) and said 'here's what we'd like to do," Andrzejewski said. City officials are open to ideas but would prefer the approved hotel on the site, he said.

But if developers want to build anything not yet approved by city officials, "they would need to get plans together and start from scratch," Andrzejewski said. Any such process would take about one year, he said.
VFREILE@Gannett.com

articleBody.value: I first started thinking about “aging well” while working at Morgan Stanley, when some of my clients started worrying more about “getting old” than outliving their money and running out of income.
“Old,” they assumed, meant frailty, sickness, boredom and filling less important roles in the world than they had been used to.

I began to listen more acutely. As people got older, they said things like “I’d better go visit my grandchildren now while I still can travel” or “I’m working on my garden now while I still can bend over.”

I started looking out for those “while I still can” sentences because they seemed to spell out what we expect to become. It was the kind of expectation that some of my clients — like so many others — were trapped in.

I started looking at my own life. I had been in the investment business for 30 years and thought I would stay in it forever. I still liked the work. But the negative views of aging all around me kept bothering me.
So at age 68, I decided to leave my job and start working toward a Ph.D., studying the possibilities of aging, both good and bad.

I embarked on a qualitative study of eight people from all over the country, ages 85 to 100, interviewing them in great depth over five years. I chose them because they were active and productive in their communities, and remarkable in their vitality and independence.
Seven years later, at age 75, I had my Ph.D. — and new insight into aging.

Beyond well-known healthy lifestyle factors, I had found several traits these people had in common that explained why they were out in the world, oblivious of their age, doing so well and contributing their talents.
Three primary traits stood out. And they have nothing to do with the illusory goal of “staying young.”
None of them had any intention of retiring — ever.
They wanted to work and they did work, all but one of them for pay, even. Why?
They felt that life needs a purpose.
“If you have useful work to do, something to take your mind off yourself, you’re going to be fine,” said Billie Gammon, one of the people I interviewed.
Some worked at their earlier life careers, others branched out into new fields.

Oren Brown had spent his whole career teaching opera singers at The Juilliard School in Manhattan. At age 95, he said: “I just keep right on working. A friend of mine at Juilliard retired and now he’s dead. Nothing to keep him going.”

When I interviewed Winona Masline, she was the president of a small local electronics firm, even though she was decades past retirement age. She got up at 5 a.m., ate her breakfast, put “a bend in her hair,” and got to work by 8 a.m. She wouldn’t get home until around 7 or 8 in the evening.
With that schedule, she never had time to catch up with everything.
Yet she didn’t feel unhappy about it. Instead, she told me: “I like to progress. I like to grow … just keep things moving. I don’t ever feel unhappy. No, I got work to do.”

Harry Gary cooked up a three-part career, layering one on another. He began as a farmer on 340 acres in the hills south of Albany. Along the way, he took to singing and playing his guitar, working at parties, parades and hospitals.
Harry Gary, “The Singing Farmer,” they called him. Hobby Lobby even hired him to sing “Nellie Grey” to a cow he brought on stage!

Then, at age 90, he decided to add a new career. He got himself a computer, learned how to “make it go” and began writing articles based on his down-to-earth philosopher’s point of view. Within a year, three regional publications were running his column, "Down on the Farm."

Mabel Lomas owned and ran an antiques business in New Hampshire in a big, old 1790s house — which she cared for herself — along with her beautiful gardens. She summed it up succinctly: “Old fools retire and lose interest — and their health.”
She and the others I interviewed suggested that work gave meaning to their lives. It provided a framework in which they grew as human beings, sharpening old skills and learning new ones.

And at a deeper level, their work let them give something of themselves to the world. Developing others’ talents, raising money for good causes, even entertaining others — all of that mattered to them.

Many people today are confronting the great “What next?” question. Having retired in their late 50s or 60s, the question is “Now what?” Staring at 30 or 40 more years of life, full-time relaxation and entertainment doesn’t cut it for people who want to stay engaged and active in the world.
This is a new problem. Not that long ago, most people died a few years after they retired. But now, many of my colleagues and I are gunning for 100.
The second shared trait I discovered was: resilience.

All my respondents expressed expectations about their lives that did not include defeat. No matter what happened — what blows they absorbed, what losses, pain, reversals — their response was not about the problems but about solutions.

A long time ago, Gary lost his 8-year-old son in a farming accident. Gary got a look in his eye when he mentioned this: distant. Hurting, 50 years later. He didn’t go into detail. What he did say was: “The only thing — what you have to do is love the people around you now … all the people. I find in each a divine spark.”

Gammon, who was a teacher and Scout leader who didn't own a car or TV, restored an old, abandoned village in Maine into a working village that functioned as an historical museum. She dressed in period costumes and performed there and hosted an annual humanities conference. For her work, she was honored at a White House luncheon with Barbara Bush and President George H.W. Bush.
When I met her, she also was a testament to resilience in the face of the smaller frustrations of life.
“My fingers don’t work very well unless I spit on them,” she explained. “They’re smooth, they’ve lost their tread, and you can’t pick up things. But that’s minor.”
So spit she did when she wanted to pick up things.

And she felt she just had to grow tomatoes for her meals. When it got hard for her to bend down in the garden, she used her two ski poles to help. And when she was done tending, since she had the ski poles in her hands, she used them to go on a little walk in the neighborhood.

Masline put it this way: “There’s always something else you can do, if you can’t do what you’re doing. No, I don’t get discouraged. Sometimes I get a little disgusted with myself to think I can’t do something, but then I think of something else to do.”
She came up with a lot of things she could do. Her first husband died, leaving her no insurance. She had no job, no money and two kids under 6. Simple solution: “Well, I had to work, so I worked.”

Somebody told her about selling real estate. She plowed into that, did very well, and was thinking about buying land for development when her second husband died. He had a small business, so Masline decided she probably ought to take the business over and run it. So she did.
Winona didn’t let much of anything bother her. She just figured out what needed to be done and did it.
Along those lines, Gary said: “If you think you can, you can. Inside of each of us are inherent yearnings … a sense of what we want. We have to take positive action to get it.”

He went on: “I used to be shy — so holding back, fear I guess, of saying something that wasn’t right or of not being liked or whatever. The biggest thing was overcoming my inward silence. I had to take positive action to correct my shyness.”
Resilience comes into play in small things and big. All the people I interviewed were knocked around seriously, growing up as they did during the Great Depression of the 1930s.

Maybe living through tough times can lead to the kind of sturdy resilience they showed. Maybe appreciation for pure survival is why I heard each of them say, one time or another,  “I’m so lucky’” “I’ve been blessed all my life;” “Everything turns out OK.”
In the face of difficulty, they remained undaunted, relying on their inner resources.
Finally, they knew how to say “NO.” Call it autonomy. Call it independence. But you couldn’t push these people around — not even at 95.
Josh Billings, the 19th-century humorist, once said: “Half the troubles of this life can be traced to saying ‘yes’ too quickly and not saying ‘no’ soon enough.”
Lomas, at 97, announced with her tart tongue: “I know who I am. I’m myself. Nobody can make decisions for me.” She followed that up with: “There isn’t anything I can’t do. I’d find a way. “
In proclaiming her right to manage her own life, she spoke to the potential fullness of age. She and the others have discovered a lot about themselves. They expect to stand on their own.
These are the bedrock feelings of self-confidence, self-reliance.

It’s a way of seeing life as pushing us into a constant process of redefinition — an ongoing update of self, wearing down and reshaping old ideas and habits, through years of learning, loving, losing and winning.
This is the brilliance of old age. The great advantage that long life bestows.  Experience, and the power that experience brings.
As  Brown put it, “With age, you only get better in wisdom, experience and inner self.”

Listen carefully to that and you’ll see that it’s not about staying young. It’s about becoming more of who we are. These people were not thinking about staying young. They were excited to be who they were. Growing. Being 88 or 95 or 100.
So 88 is not the new 68. It’s the new 88. It’s up to each of us to define what that’s like.
